componenttext: It's Europe as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So on the Templeton Global Bond, just a couple of questions there. At what point does capacity start to be a factor? Two, who are the incremental buyers of the fund? And three, to what extent does the management team, do you guys as the management team, h
componenttext: So on the Templeton Global Bond, just a couple of questions there. At what point does capacity start to be a factor? Two, who are the incremental buyers of the fund? And three, to what extent does the management team, do you guys as the management team, have concerns about how this fund performs in a rising rate environment?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, first of all, capacity in any of our funds is something that we're concerned about and if the portfolio managers feel that it's time to consider closing a fund, we will do that. And we've done that in the past, so that's something we're ver
componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, capacity in any of our funds is something that we're concerned about and if the portfolio managers feel that it's time to consider closing a fund, we will do that. And we've done that in the past, so that's something we're very aware of. But I think that the general statement regarding flows and where we had $10 billion of net inflows was into a global government bond fund. And a government bond fund, obviously, you have tremendous capacity and growing capacity. And then also currency is the other area. So the liquidity of derivatives around currency forwards and things that you have to use in a fund like that, again, it’s one of the most liquid in large markets. So while we have a large share of a new class of flows, it is dwarfed by the overall size of that market. So there's really very little concern. If you had that much going in Emerging Markets Debt, that may be a different discussion on liquidity to consider having to close. I think the question around buyers is an interesting one because I think part of this growth is the recognition, certainly on the retail side, of a new asset class that is less correlated in a way to typical fixed income to equities. It had a very strong overall performance number and obviously, active management is the only way to really play that market. And trying to get currencies right, obviously, is very challenging as well. But we've had a team that has been successful in doing that. And I think looking at the average retail investor, they're more open to putting a portion of their assets in that. So I think that's part of what you're seeing in that class, and it's still a very relatively small number of the typical retail investor's portfolio. So I think that's a good trend that bodes well for continued new investors in that category. And then finally on rates, I think you're a little bit less sensitive to rates and we do -- I mean, obviously, it’s fixed income. Currencies are going to be a big driver, but we also look at duration and are very focused then because it's not as much of an income-oriented fund. We can go a little bit shorter on duration than our typical longer-term maturity fixed income fund. So that helps a little bit. But the bottom line is that it's very challenging to manage in this space. And there are going to be times when you're going to be out of favor and wrong. To us, we're trying to build that into the selling process that, that should be part of your expectation. You're never going to call every move in currencies, but I think we feel like we've got one of the best teams out there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Robert Lee with KBW.
componenttext: Our next question is from Robert Lee with KBW.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question on the regulatory front or legal front. Who knows what happens if the Dodd bill has been included in that is obviously the, I guess, the Volcker Rules. And unfortunately for you guys, if I remember correctly, you are regulated as a bank
componenttext: I have a question on the regulatory front or legal front. Who knows what happens if the Dodd bill has been included in that is obviously the, I guess, the Volcker Rules. And unfortunately for you guys, if I remember correctly, you are regulated as a bank holding company. So I know nothing has been set in stone. But what flexibility -- I mean, do you have the flexibility if that came to pass to change your holding company structure? I assume you do so that you wouldn't be subject to any of the rules as it relates to private equity or other holdings?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as you said, I mean, it's hard because things are moving so quickly and the bottom line is we don't have to be a bank holding company. It's a complementary part of a few of our businesses that even today, we're looking at the overall structur
componenttext: Yes, I think as you said, I mean, it's hard because things are moving so quickly and the bottom line is we don't have to be a bank holding company. It's a complementary part of a few of our businesses that even today, we're looking at the overall structure and trying to rationalize the right future, but we can't really do that until we know what the regulatory landscape is going to look like. So you're right. I mean, today, we fall under that, under the Volcker Rule. You probably -- I'm not even sure we can seed funds. I'm not sure how any of these would work in practice. And I think we've got a long ways to go before we get too worried about what impact it may or may not have. But I think the bottom line is we feel even in the worst-case scenario that we could restructure the business and not have a big impact to get it from a different structure away from the Fed structure. But even that, there's been discussion that: well, we're not going to allow people to switch. So I'm not sure what that means either. I just think things are moving in a very fluid rate now. We're participating in Washington where we can, but I don't feel that there's anything there today that would present a huge challenge for us.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe shifting to the institutional business. Just curious, I mean, a couple of competitors here or there have talked about being impacted in the quarter by client re-balancing, kind of taking advantage of the rebounds in the market for the past year
componenttext: And maybe shifting to the institutional business. Just curious, I mean, a couple of competitors here or there have talked about being impacted in the quarter by client re-balancing, kind of taking advantage of the rebounds in the market for the past year and using that as an opportunity to re-balance. Generally, it seems like a way from long-only equity strategies to some extent. I mean, it doesn't seem like that's impacted your business much in the quarter. Can you just comment a little bit? Did you see some of that? And maybe at what pockets it was in, if you did see it. Or why do you think maybe that didn't affect you guys as much in the quarter?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we did see it. I think we've seen it the last two or three quarters and the re-balancing. And any time that you have a sector do well, like Global Equities or Emerging Markets, they tend to -- there’ll be a little bit of trim into those cer
componenttext: Yes. I think we did see it. I think we've seen it the last two or three quarters and the re-balancing. And any time that you have a sector do well, like Global Equities or Emerging Markets, they tend to -- there’ll be a little bit of trim into those certain accounts. So we have seen that, they're just not -- I think on a relative basis, they're not big numbers. They're relatively small.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have seen a pickup. And we've seen a pick-up and one of the ways we measure these campaigns internally is the number of new advisers selling equity funds. And that's an important metric for us. And we have been hitting a new audience really every month
componenttext: We have seen a pickup. And we've seen a pick-up and one of the ways we measure these campaigns internally is the number of new advisers selling equity funds. And that's an important metric for us. And we have been hitting a new audience really every month. And so that's been a nice positive. We've seen positive flows going into our equity funds like the Franklin Growth Fund and the rising dividends and so the focus has been there. It's just on a relative basis compared to everything else, it's dwarfed. But the numbers are positive and they are growing. I think just overall from the retail, in terms of general statements, Mutual Series in the U.S. has had outflows. So that's put a little bit of drag on just looking at the U.S. equity numbers. And a lot of that is somewhat expected for us when you've had the higher cash positions, and their deep values style tends to kind of underperform the kind of market that we've had over the last year. So I think it's -- we feel like we are getting the attention there. It's difficult, but I just don't think the overall landscape is going to change a whole lot in the next quarter or two as far as flows go.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't agree with that. I would clarify that I think it's more on an investment objective and less so on a jurisdictional basis. And generally speaking, I think the increase in sales internationally won't impact overall profitability that much. So it'
componenttext: I wouldn't agree with that. I would clarify that I think it's more on an investment objective and less so on a jurisdictional basis. And generally speaking, I think the increase in sales internationally won't impact overall profitability that much. So it's more a question of the asset mix shifting to the equity assets.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Douglas Sipkin with Ticonderoga.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from Douglas Sipkin with Ticonderoga.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to drill down a little bit more on the global fixed income. And I don't know if you guys have provided at booking. Can you possibly just give us some ranges as to how much of that AUM, $97 billion, I believe is institutional-based? And corresp
componenttext: Just wanted to drill down a little bit more on the global fixed income. And I don't know if you guys have provided at booking. Can you possibly just give us some ranges as to how much of that AUM, $97 billion, I believe is institutional-based? And correspondingly, how much of the flows generally come from institutions versus retails? And then just for the follow-up on that, you did a really good job discussing sort of retail, highlighting that it's sort of a new asset class and therefore, the potential is probably better than people think. But how about on the institutional side? Are institutional investors seeing it that way as well?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, first of all, I don't have all of the data in front of me to tell you exactly how it breaks down institutionally. I can tell you that the majority, $10 billion of the net flows going into global bond funds split between the U.S. and interna
componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, I don't have all of the data in front of me to tell you exactly how it breaks down institutionally. I can tell you that the majority, $10 billion of the net flows going into global bond funds split between the U.S. and international sales, obviously, make up the majority of the overall flows. We did have some separate account wins, and I don't have the aggregate number, but there were some at $300 million, $200 million and maybe we can help you further with the Investor Relations group. But I just don't have it broken out in front of me other than to give you the sense that within that category, it clearly is retail that is driving probably 80%, 90% of those flows and that's a guesstimate, but that's probably close.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just in terms of -- I guesstimate it's fair to assume that the institutional demand hasn't really changed all that much. Or is the outlook for sort of global, emerging et cetera, increasing, or flattening or sort of decreasing from sort of a RFP
componenttext: And then just in terms of -- I guesstimate it's fair to assume that the institutional demand hasn't really changed all that much. Or is the outlook for sort of global, emerging et cetera, increasing, or flattening or sort of decreasing from sort of a RFP standpoint?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's steady. I think it's a little bit different than the retail because it's not strictly the global bond or the global government bond fund. It's more geared towards Emerging Market Debt in some other cases, or Global Ag, Global Core. So it's a
componenttext: I think it's steady. I think it's a little bit different than the retail because it's not strictly the global bond or the global government bond fund. It's more geared towards Emerging Market Debt in some other cases, or Global Ag, Global Core. So it's a little bit different, and we still are seeing a very steady RFP flow in those categories.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our final question is from Roger Freeman with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our final question is from Roger Freeman with Barclays Capital.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just coming back to the U.S. flows. So with, I guess, the Mutual Series is distorting I guess if we look at it for the aggregate U.S. flows. But where --how do you look at where those are positioned vis-à-vis their cash balances today? Or when do you sor
componenttext: Just coming back to the U.S. flows. So with, I guess, the Mutual Series is distorting I guess if we look at it for the aggregate U.S. flows. But where --how do you look at where those are positioned vis-à-vis their cash balances today? Or when do you sort of annualize or get past some of the headwinds from a return on perspective that, that impacted?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there'll always be short-term challenges when you have investment styles that go to cash in some markets. And you're never going to -- again, you're never going to find that right in the short-term. And that's why we spend a lot of time talking ab
componenttext: I think there'll always be short-term challenges when you have investment styles that go to cash in some markets. And you're never going to -- again, you're never going to find that right in the short-term. And that's why we spend a lot of time talking about building three- and five- and 10-year track records. And I think people somewhat -- they expect that, but there always is a short-term orientation on results. And I think with the Mutual Series funds, the cash levels are down. They're down in the teens and low teens in most cases so you won't have the kind of drag that you had before. And hopefully for us, it's just how historically that group has run money. And in some cases, you're going to have these kinds of periods where they underperform. But again, if you look at the longer-term numbers and how strong they are, I think that's really more important than the one-year number. And you look at something like the Franklin Income fund, for example, that we had short-term challenges. They’ve had sufficiently higher weightings in financial services. And during the period when financial service banks were in a lot of trouble, that fund underperformed. But quickly, it's really more uplift now in the numbers. And it's back to being a top performer for the one-year period and that kind of smoothes out over the three and five. And we've seen the quick rebound in flows there. And that was probably one of the most important funds for us as far as flows and continues to be very important to us going forward. But it shows you how quickly things can turn around on the short-term basis and not really hurt your long-term numbers when you have those little blips.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess my second question would be just around sort of the strategic outlook, particularly around M&A. What are the -- can you characterize the types of properties that are for sale at this point? I mean last year, obviously, there were the instituti
componenttext: And I guess my second question would be just around sort of the strategic outlook, particularly around M&A. What are the -- can you characterize the types of properties that are for sale at this point? I mean last year, obviously, there were the institutions -- asset management firms coming out of financial institution looking to raise capital, presumably less of that, although maybe some of the smaller institutions. Or are we sort of back to the sort of historical landscape in terms of diversification of ownership, generational issues, those types of things?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, yes, probably fair. I mean I think the day of the more distressed sales has probably passed. The one of manufacturing and distribution separating is probably somewhat passed. And then you'll always have generational transfers and just people that
componenttext: I think, yes, probably fair. I mean I think the day of the more distressed sales has probably passed. The one of manufacturing and distribution separating is probably somewhat passed. And then you'll always have generational transfers and just people that feel like their company will be better positioned within a larger institution. And I think some of that in this world, having gone through this cycle and risk management and how that becomes more important to the investor to be part of a larger organization. I think does create more smaller situations. And we've had a lot of conversations where that's been an important focus to them, the distribution side. And just the importance of being within a larger organization that has all the resources to make sure that you're looking at risk, and compliance, and everything, and more importantly, from their client size. So I think you will see a lot of opportunities, as always, in this industry. I mean, there's always opportunity out there and we're continuing to look at everything.

componenttext: Okay. Well, thanks everyone for your time and we'll talk to you next quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Franklin Resources earnings conference call for the quarter ended June 30, 2010. My name is Michael and I will be your conference operator today.Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Franklin Resources earnings conference call for the quarter ended June 30, 2010. My name is Michael and I will be your conference operator today.
Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference call are preliminary. Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements.
These and other risks, uncertainties, and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin’s recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and the MD&A sections of Franklin’s most recent Form 10-K and 10-Q filing. After the speakers’ remarks, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. (Operator instructions) Now, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good afternoon, everyone. I am Greg Johnson, CEO, along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. As always thanks for taking time today to join us this afternoon and hopefully, you had a chance to listen to the commentary that we made available this morning
componenttext:
Thank you and good afternoon, everyone. I am Greg Johnson, CEO, along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. As always thanks for taking time today to join us this afternoon and hopefully, you had a chance to listen to the commentary that we made available this morning.
I’d like to recap a few of the highlights. This was another very strong quarter despite some challenging global markets and most importantly, investment performance remained strong with over 80% of our assets ranked in the top half of their peer groups for the three-year, five-year and 10-year periods. Long-term net inflows of $18.2 billion, which was a new record for us and through three quarters of our fiscal year, we’ve had three quarters of our four best quarters ever. I would now like to open it up for your questions. Thank you.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions) Your first question comes from the line of Roger Freeman with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: (Operator instructions) Your first question comes from the line of Roger Freeman with Barclays Capital.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good evening. I guess, first question, with respect to the new financial reform legislation and sort of bank holding company rules around limiting seed investments for funds management, what are your thoughts around that, given your structure and how
componenttext: Hi, good evening. I guess, first question, with respect to the new financial reform legislation and sort of bank holding company rules around limiting seed investments for funds management, what are your thoughts around that, given your structure and how you may respond to them.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think like most, we have been very focused and we are a bank holding company and looking at what impact it may have, but I think like most, it’s a little bit early to speculate. I think our feeling is that once it works its way through the process, wh
componenttext:
I think like most, we have been very focused and we are a bank holding company and looking at what impact it may have, but I think like most, it’s a little bit early to speculate. I think our feeling is that once it works its way through the process, which could take a while, many studies to be done, many new rules to come out, will get some clarity around the issue.
I think as far as the issue of seeding funds, while that may look like that could be a problem, we don’t anticipate that it should be a problem, but that risk is certainly out there. I think again with our status of a holding company, it’s something that we could change by stop offering some non-core services, but there is also a risk of being deemed a systemically important non-bank company. So that hangs out there as well. So, we really just need a bit of time to get some clarity around these before we really can determine exactly how it will affect us. I think we feel confident that issues like seed capital should be worked out.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: My second question, just, I guess, around your Global Bond Funds, the returns in the quarter I guess it looks like the Templeton Global Bond was down 2.5% or so. Looking against like the Barclays Global Ag Index, which was about flat, can you talk at all
componenttext: My second question, just, I guess, around your Global Bond Funds, the returns in the quarter I guess it looks like the Templeton Global Bond was down 2.5% or so. Looking against like the Barclays Global Ag Index, which was about flat, can you talk at all about how that your Global Fund is maybe positioned relative to an index like that or either regionally or sort of within the yield curve?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I can speak in general terms, but again, I am not the PM [ph], so I’d be careful in having me discuss how we’re positioned because that could have changed from where I looked at it the last time, but we had been negative on the euro and positive on As
componenttext: I can speak in general terms, but again, I am not the PM [ph], so I’d be careful in having me discuss how we’re positioned because that could have changed from where I looked at it the last time, but we had been negative on the euro and positive on Asian currencies. With the euro rebounding somewhat during that period, I am sure that led to some underperformance. But, as far as short-term performance goes and especially in this actively managed fund, there is going to be periods where you underperform the indices. I think that our team is in a better position to address that, and again, I think the overall performance speaks for itself.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Katz with Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Katz with Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone. I guess, two questions. Number one, was thinking about almost a 30% organic growth rate outside the United States. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the dynamics behind that and maybe any sort of pip
componenttext: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone. I guess, two questions. Number one, was thinking about almost a 30% organic growth rate outside the United States. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the dynamics behind that and maybe any sort of pipeline into the new quarter [ph] will be interesting and I have a follow on.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that kind of growth rate is going to be difficult to stand. I mean I think you had some unusual events and certainly we talked about the euro and how that actually accelerated some of the Global Bond sales throughout Europe, as people divers
componenttext:
Well, I think that kind of growth rate is going to be difficult to stand. I mean I think you had some unusual events and certainly we talked about the euro and how that actually accelerated some of the Global Bond sales throughout Europe, as people diversified away from the euro. So we were the net beneficiary. I don’t think that’s a long-term sustainable trend. I think it’s important to point out that we have seen very significant close in other categories in SICAV, our Asian Growth Funds have been one of our top sellers there. As well as the Emerging Markets Fund, and also even within fixed income many different types of bond funds, we had the Asian Bond Fund which had over a billion in net sales, has really started to accelerate its growth.
So, as far as organic growth rates, I mean those are hard to forecast, but I think it has been a usual period with respect to the growth of Global Bonds. But I think we are getting the benefit of somewhat of the halo effect when you have something as strong as a Global Bonds category that that’s really helping our other funds as well as our equity funds. For next quarter, I mean we talked about the one large account that should fund. So I mean, obviously, that’s going to help when you just look at offshore organic growth rates, but again that’s a one-time event of $4 billion that should come in this quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: To your earlier question just in terms I think investors concern on the stock is the concentration of the flows. Looks like, this quarter it was down to roughly half the volume versus down 60% last quarter. Is there anything you’re doing at the wholesal
componenttext: To your earlier question just in terms I think investors concern on the stock is the concentration of the flows. Looks like, this quarter it was down to roughly half the volume versus down 60% last quarter. Is there anything you’re doing at the wholesale level to try and modify behavior? Maybe its payouts incentives, I am not sure exactly what that would look to further diversify the platform?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that’s something that we are focused on and again the incentives for all of our sales people have specific metrics around diversifying the book and diversifying it by advisor, and that’s something that we recognize is a risk. But if you looked
componenttext:
I think that’s something that we are focused on and again the incentives for all of our sales people have specific metrics around diversifying the book and diversifying it by advisor, and that’s something that we recognize is a risk. But if you looked at our marketing efforts today, certainly on the retail side with our 2020 Vision Campaign, that’s very much focused on trying to get investors to look at equities, because we think especially on the retail side that probably too much money is moving into the fixed income at these lower yields.
We want to make sure that the people recognize the risks there and are looking to equities. I think the timing has been good with that campaign, because we’ve seen our Franklin Equity Group continue to perform very well. I think 75% of its assets were in the top quartile for the last year. So I think if you combine those two, hopefully, we’ll get a little bit of momentum when things turn there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Fannon with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Fannon with Jefferies.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. You guys have talked previously about kind of the gatekeepers, the consultants looking at the Global Bond as a new category. I’m wondering if you can update on this in terms some of the institutional, potential channels opening up are ne
componenttext: Good afternoon. You guys have talked previously about kind of the gatekeepers, the consultants looking at the Global Bond as a new category. I’m wondering if you can update on this in terms some of the institutional, potential channels opening up are new or more opportunities there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that’s certainly been the case. I mean when you look at the category 10 years ago, it’s very small. So even though it’s grown quite a bit, it represents a relatively small position on the retail and as well as the institutional side, and we
componenttext:
I think that’s certainly been the case. I mean when you look at the category 10 years ago, it’s very small. So even though it’s grown quite a bit, it represents a relatively small position on the retail and as well as the institutional side, and we have, especially here in the States, a very dominant share of the growing asset class. I think the other good news is that it’s a very large asset class when you’re look at sovereign debt, the liquidity, and the scale and how big a fund can be in that category.
So, I think all of those are positive, and obviously, the trend towards fixed income and we’re seeing that on the institutional side as well in more of the Global Ag mandates and Emerging Markets mandates, but that pipeline still looks very healthy.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then Ken, on the number side, just heading into your fiscal year end for next quarter, should there be any seasonality to the comp or the comp ratio as we think about a catch-up given the strength in sales and your guys pretty strong growth rate?
componenttext: And then Ken, on the number side, just heading into your fiscal year end for next quarter, should there be any seasonality to the comp or the comp ratio as we think about a catch-up given the strength in sales and your guys pretty strong growth rate?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. There was that non-recurring item this quarter of $12.5 million and I guess that implies, from my point of view, a run rate that’s probably a little bit on the low side. But of course, it’s dependent on revenue and with the markets dipping
componenttext: Yes, sure. There was that non-recurring item this quarter of $12.5 million and I guess that implies, from my point of view, a run rate that’s probably a little bit on the low side. But of course, it’s dependent on revenue and with the markets dipping in May, you might see a little bit of a drop in revenue. But all that said, I think we’ll see a little bit of an upward pressure on the top line, not too much but just little.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, can you just maybe give us your thoughts on kind of retail investor sentiment more broadly? It seems like we are in somewhat of a holding period, where retail investors just aren’t really coming back into equities for the time being. Do you get th
componenttext: Greg, can you just maybe give us your thoughts on kind of retail investor sentiment more broadly? It seems like we are in somewhat of a holding period, where retail investors just aren’t really coming back into equities for the time being. Do you get the sense that this could be kind of a multi-year process? Or what do you think we need to see in order to maybe speed that process up?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you probably know the answer. I mean it’s really what happens with the market. I think that investor was coming back and flows were improving, but after the flash crash and then some of the debt problems over the quarter, retail investor t
componenttext:
Well, I think you probably know the answer. I mean it’s really what happens with the market. I think that investor was coming back and flows were improving, but after the flash crash and then some of the debt problems over the quarter, retail investor tends to retreat. It’s not so much redemption as it is, they just stop putting new monies and so the net numbers tend to look a lot worse than you would think.
So for us, we are going to keep talking about equities, we are going keep pushing our 2020 Vision Campaign and I think they will come back, but it’s a function of what the economy does, what confidence levels are out there. Right now, it’s just not very high. I think there is still good flows going into more packaged products, variable annuities, 401(k) are still relatively positive, but it’s just the discretionary equity additions to portfolios that I think are under the most stressed.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe, can you just give us an update on activity levels on the institutional side more broadly and then just the mandate that set the fund this quarter, what type of strategy is that?
componenttext: And then maybe, can you just give us an update on activity levels on the institutional side more broadly and then just the mandate that set the fund this quarter, what type of strategy is that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think first of all, with regard to just the pipeline and I don’t think there has been any real shift, I mean it’s still Global Fixed Income, Global Ag, emerging markets debt, and global equities for us and occasionally some other classes, but
componenttext:
Well, I think first of all, with regard to just the pipeline and I don’t think there has been any real shift, I mean it’s still Global Fixed Income, Global Ag, emerging markets debt, and global equities for us and occasionally some other classes, but that would represent the bulk. We are still seeing very strong activity there. The fund, dual fund was a multi-year effort for us that had to go through some government approvals to move the monies over to an outside manager. That has taken place. So we hope to have that $4 billion account in.
As far as fees go, I would just say that while we don’t disclose specific fees but it’s something where you would expect an institutional global mandate and this when you say what does it look like, it doesn’t look like anything because it’s a closed end fund remaining in securities and that is a new category for us certainly. We have to add people and we just opened up the office in Bucharest here in the last few weeks.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JP Morgan.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: First, performance fees this quarter, was that mostly Darby, and if so, what are the assets that are generating this performance fees? I think they are only $2.3 billion in your K? How big are they today?
componenttext: First, performance fees this quarter, was that mostly Darby, and if so, what are the assets that are generating this performance fees? I think they are only $2.3 billion in your K? How big are they today?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: They were split between Darby and some of our emerging markets products. Still the performance fees as a percentage of assets under management very small. These are things that are hard to predict. I guess the concentration of the investments might have b
componenttext: They were split between Darby and some of our emerging markets products. Still the performance fees as a percentage of assets under management very small. These are things that are hard to predict. I guess the concentration of the investments might have been more skewed towards Latin America. I don’t think performance fees have been the material part of our revenue story and I don’t expect they will be in the near future.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: What’s the asset base?
componenttext: What’s the asset base?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess it was both Darby and Emerging Markets. I think it’s about like less than 1% or 2% of AUM.
componenttext: I guess it was both Darby and Emerging Markets. I think it’s about like less than 1% or 2% of AUM.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, on Canada. Canada has been in redemption each and every month this year and it seems like in the Canadian market, the Dynamic Funds and Fidelity are taking huge share. So what’s going on with the Franklin business in Canada and what i
componenttext: And then secondly, on Canada. Canada has been in redemption each and every month this year and it seems like in the Canadian market, the Dynamic Funds and Fidelity are taking huge share. So what’s going on with the Franklin business in Canada and what is it going to take to turn that business around?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you’re right. It has been a very challenging market, especially for any firm that has global equity funds. In that category, the Canadian market has been very strong as you’d expect with the strength in commodities that really drives that mark
componenttext:
I think you’re right. It has been a very challenging market, especially for any firm that has global equity funds. In that category, the Canadian market has been very strong as you’d expect with the strength in commodities that really drives that market, so most of the monies are going to go into domestic mandates.
For us, we diversified away from the flagship Templeton Growth Fund in that market and have been very successful with more of an allocation story up there and that continues to do very well. The other issue was the concentration of distribution. There is more distribution happening through banks and captive sales forces. I think that’s something that any outside manager needs to look at in the future, but it’s just been harder and harder for the independent manager, and I think that goes against the trend we see in the rest of the world.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Lee with KBW.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Lee with KBW.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is, if I think back a couple of quarters, markets were better all around and the general sense is that you guys have started to loosen the reins a little bit on investment spend, I mean not dramatically but starting to spend a little bit
componenttext: My first question is, if I think back a couple of quarters, markets were better all around and the general sense is that you guys have started to loosen the reins a little bit on investment spend, I mean not dramatically but starting to spend a little bit more money on new initiatives and maybe you had in the year or so prior. Given where we were and what the markets did the last quarter and where we are right now, what’s your current view from an expense perspective? Is there a backlog of projects you need to get to? With your pretty strong volume, is that keeping the pressure on having to spend on infrastructure?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So we are going through the budget process right now, and I wouldn’t characterize it as tremendous a backlog of request for spend. We clearly want to leverage the success that we have and the opportunities that we’re seeing from those successes, and w
componenttext: So we are going through the budget process right now, and I wouldn’t characterize it as tremendous a backlog of request for spend. We clearly want to leverage the success that we have and the opportunities that we’re seeing from those successes, and we’re committed to do that. I think the bulk of the expense requests are to invest in operations outside the U.S. in portfolio and distribution. When we get those requests, they usually come with at least some objective of generating revenue. So if your question is about margin compression or expansion, I think we try to take a balanced approach and we’d just prioritize the investments based on what we think the potential payback is.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe in part a follow-up to an earlier question. If you look through your various managers, I’m thinking mainly of Darby and I guess its Franklin Real Estate Advisors, I guess they are predominantly where you would have different alternative strategies
componenttext: Maybe in part a follow-up to an earlier question. If you look through your various managers, I’m thinking mainly of Darby and I guess its Franklin Real Estate Advisors, I guess they are predominantly where you would have different alternative strategies and a classic definitions. As you look in the institutional world, I mean there is certainly more dollars being targeted towards alternative strategies broadly around the world. Do you think that those are big enough platforms to really grow meaningfully? Or do you think that, just broadly within alternatives, is that an area where you want to try to increase focus whether it’s through acquisitions, team lift-outs, kind of what are your thoughts there?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we are watching certainly institutional market and where our fees are going and the increased allocation towards the alternatives continue as the expected returns on traditional loan-only equities and fixed income are continuing to decline.
componenttext:
Well, I think we are watching certainly institutional market and where our fees are going and the increased allocation towards the alternatives continue as the expected returns on traditional loan-only equities and fixed income are continuing to decline. We have to meet that liability there. So, we are very aware of that.
As we stated before, we have to fit in an alternatives manager that makes sense within our given structure and also with the right kind of economic incentives to maintain a transition, whether it’s an acquisition or partial ownership and something that we are doing today, that’s a little bit different than what we’ve done in the past just to take minority stakes.
That hasn’t been so much the case now, but something we are to open to doing with the emerging managers in the alternative space rather than just going in and acquiring in outright but taking minority stake, working with them and increasing that stake from there. So I think that’s just recognition of it. It’s a little bit different business for us and doesn’t necessarily fit in, in the more traditional acquisition of a mutual fund company for more activity there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Carrier with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Carrier with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just in the international fixed income bucket, just wanted to try to get a little bit more clarity or granularity. We all focus on the Global Bond Fund, but just what other products are in that mix that are benefiting as well? And then from a flow perspec
componenttext: Just in the international fixed income bucket, just wanted to try to get a little bit more clarity or granularity. We all focus on the Global Bond Fund, but just what other products are in that mix that are benefiting as well? And then from a flow perspective, any granularity on where it’s coming from, so whether it’s retail institutional, U.S., non-U.S.? And then knowing those investors, just if that product or that new asset classes starts to lose its luster, like where will they head and regarding your position you know to take advantage of that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that’s a good question. That’s some of the point I made earlier about looking at flows and other categories for us within fixed income. In a Global total return, which is a SICAV fund had 2.7 billion, it’s a Global Ag, it’s a traditional s
componenttext:
I think that’s a good question. That’s some of the point I made earlier about looking at flows and other categories for us within fixed income. In a Global total return, which is a SICAV fund had 2.7 billion, it’s a Global Ag, it’s a traditional sovereign plus corporate and that had $2.7 billion in net inflows versus $2.2 billion in the prior quarter within our SICAV lineup. Emerging Market Bond Fund had $1 billion in net sales versus $700 million in the prior quarter.
The Asian Bond Fund on $1 billion base had over $1 billion in net sales with the net quarter end up at a $2.2 billion base. So those are some other funds that are doing extremely well. As far as the retail, institutional, the U.S. is going to be primarily retail using the fund, almost all retail. Outside of the U.S. is going to be a little bit of both with a lot of those dollars coming from Europe and places like Switzerland, in particular.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one question on the cash. You raised the debts and now you have even more cash. You did the buybacks and I think historically you guys always point out whether it’s with the special dividends the buybacks, the current dividends, it was a b
componenttext: And then just one question on the cash. You raised the debts and now you have even more cash. You did the buybacks and I think historically you guys always point out whether it’s with the special dividends the buybacks, the current dividends, it was a big payout. When you look at the portion that’s in the U.S. versus outside the U.S. just an update on that, but then more importantly how do you gauge that decision on bringing more cash into the U.S. paying taxes, wait for a tax holiday, just what goes through your mind in terms of when you make that decision.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure we’ll give you the exact figure for our forecast, but I think after the debt raise, we’re close back to that 50-50. So in terms of our repatriation policy and all that, the international area is our area of growth. So, the basis bias is to leave
componenttext: Sure we’ll give you the exact figure for our forecast, but I think after the debt raise, we’re close back to that 50-50. So in terms of our repatriation policy and all that, the international area is our area of growth. So, the basis bias is to leave the money there and invest it in the foreign operations, because that’s where we’re seeing a lot of growth. And then the overall overwriting concept is the return to shareholders, and we’ve been fairly consistent in the percentages of our payout ratio being what percentage of net income we return to shareholders with dividends and share repurchases. So that’s really what we’re looking at and I think we have plenty of financial flexibility to continuing that history being shareholder-friendly. When that gets to point where it’s jeopardizing, I think we’ll have to revisit our situation.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Cynthia Mayer with Bank of America.

componenttext: Yes, I read that article as well and I didn’t see or hear of that any redemptions that were made for that reason. But certainly, I think that’s something to be aware of. The big win for us was the $790 million small cap fund that came in over the quarter and no real outside of that, it’s Mutual Series, it’s Templeton, it really is fairly well-diversified in the annuity channel.

componenttext: That’s our closed accounts that we keep for a year and then purge them once a year. So, closed accounts, probably, for increased redemptions last year.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Marc Irizarry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Marc Irizarry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, you know the non-U.S. sales continue to be very impressive and I’m sure you’re continuing to gain momentum and a lot of different reasons out there. Can you talk about the reasons where you’re seeing the most momentum? And then also, how does
componenttext: Greg, you know the non-U.S. sales continue to be very impressive and I’m sure you’re continuing to gain momentum and a lot of different reasons out there. Can you talk about the reasons where you’re seeing the most momentum? And then also, how does the strategy of M&A of local managers fit into where you ultimately can see your market share overseas?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It really hasn’t changed. I mean, we think that having a local manager, if you’re going to develop a strong presence in a given retail market and they have a demand for local management, we want to be there in that market. I don’t think that’s cha
componenttext:
It really hasn’t changed. I mean, we think that having a local manager, if you’re going to develop a strong presence in a given retail market and they have a demand for local management, we want to be there in that market. I don’t think that’s changed. I just think you have an unusual period right now and with Southern Europe, and Italy, Spain, with the euro that have accelerated fixed income sales.
I think, generally, you can make the statement that that’s probably going to be less sticky than traditional-type money because the nature of what people are doing if euro goes the other way, that could move. So I think you have to be sensitive on to that. But I make our strategy of continuing to develop local asset managers hasn’t changed at all. I mean there is only a couple of markets that you would say have an addressable retail markets, that we’re not in right now and those are ones that we’re certainly looking at.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a bit about the taxable fixed income growth? Obviously, the gross sales accelerated, but so is the redemption rate. Can you speak a little bit about the dynamic there just in taxable fixed income? Obviously, on the sales side, it seemed like
componenttext: Can you talk a bit about the taxable fixed income growth? Obviously, the gross sales accelerated, but so is the redemption rate. Can you speak a little bit about the dynamic there just in taxable fixed income? Obviously, on the sales side, it seemed like maybe the euro was accelerating some non-U.S. sales, but what happened in terms of redemptions in the quarter?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don’t think they moved up a little bit, but on the fixed income side and I don’t think it was a dramatic change and it is interesting when gross sales increase, that redemptions tend to increase, and I have never understood that looking at ret
componenttext: Well, I don’t think they moved up a little bit, but on the fixed income side and I don’t think it was a dramatic change and it is interesting when gross sales increase, that redemptions tend to increase, and I have never understood that looking at retail sales for a long time, that you would expect them to stay stable when things are increasing but they tend to move up on just for whatever reason for the activity. So, I don’t have a good answer on why taxable fixed would have increased the redemption activity over the period, but I can say it wasn’t really much.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Farr with CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Farr with CLSA.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: My question is related to how your teams are structured, particularly in the global fixed income side? Just more I get questions from clients on like say key person risk in particular funds, I just want to know how your teams are structured in if the Glob
componenttext: My question is related to how your teams are structured, particularly in the global fixed income side? Just more I get questions from clients on like say key person risk in particular funds, I just want to know how your teams are structured in if the Global Bond Fund and the Global Total Return Fund are at the same management team?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: They are not for those two examples, but the global fixed is headed up specifically by Dr. Hasenstab who obviously is a very high profile throughout really the world on both institutional and retail, and a team that we continue to build underneath him. So
componenttext:
They are not for those two examples, but the global fixed is headed up specifically by Dr. Hasenstab who obviously is a very high profile throughout really the world on both institutional and retail, and a team that we continue to build underneath him. So I think our feeling is that stars get developed in this industry, it’s a risk we know and we want to make sure we have a deep bench and a consistent process that we can repeat, but that’s certainly always a risk, but we are well aware of that risk.
And then within the other, all of the taxable fixed is a separate team as well and the munis are a separate team. It’s all headed up by one person, who runs fixed income, but we have four or five different CIOs within fixed income for the different strategies and Michael Hasenstab is one of those with the Global Bond.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then one quick follow-up. I think you’ve touched on this earlier, just getting traction on the local funds, particularly on the equity side, can you just give us sense like when some of the strategies you guys can employ like say whether it’s in I
componenttext: And then one quick follow-up. I think you’ve touched on this earlier, just getting traction on the local funds, particularly on the equity side, can you just give us sense like when some of the strategies you guys can employ like say whether it’s in India or other Asian markets or even European markets?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think each market you are going to look at them, the local managers have done very well this year, but we are not talking about it because I think it’s just as a percentage of the total numbers, it looks fairly small. India has been an example f
componenttext:
Well, I think each market you are going to look at them, the local managers have done very well this year, but we are not talking about it because I think it’s just as a percentage of the total numbers, it looks fairly small. India has been an example for us where we have increased market share considerably and that’s been a real success story here where we had lost some share over the last few years and that’s on the back of very strong performance in that local market. Those markets are going to take time.
I mean you are just not going to get the kind of momentum you can get from developed markets for all of the sudden your mix is in favor where the market is going, it’s certainly our mix has been in the right spot for a lot of the more developed markets, but that doesn’t change our thinking on the other Asia, India, the other markets that’s going to take a longer time to develop

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Douglas Sipkin with Ticonderoga Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Douglas Sipkin with Ticonderoga Securities.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to expand a little bit on marketing expense. I know you guys provided a little bit of detail on the prerecorded call. But some of your competitors talked about spending more now. I mean are you guys feeling more pressure that you’re going to
componenttext: Just wanted to expand a little bit on marketing expense. I know you guys provided a little bit of detail on the prerecorded call. But some of your competitors talked about spending more now. I mean are you guys feeling more pressure that you’re going to need to go above and beyond what you’ve been doing? I know you’ve leading the pack on spending on the marketing side. Or do you feel pretty comfortable with where you’re trending and even though it sounds like comps are moving up, you don’t feel like you need to change all that much?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don’t think we need to make any dramatic change to our strategy. I’ve been saying for a couple of quarters that we had planned and continue to increase advertising spend, I think that trend will continue. It was offset a little bit this quarter
componenttext: Yes. I don’t think we need to make any dramatic change to our strategy. I’ve been saying for a couple of quarters that we had planned and continue to increase advertising spend, I think that trend will continue. It was offset a little bit this quarter by reduced promotion, but certainly the advertising spend was up this quarter. I expect that to increase next quarter too, not a lot but a little bit. Like I said, no change in our strategy, it’s just we made commitments and we’ll probably see them come through in future quarters.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just a follow-up. I know you addressed it also on the prerecorded about some of the changes the SEC is proposing. Can you maybe talk a little bit about how you guys see your business evolving through that? Any potential spots that you’re
componenttext: Great. And then just a follow-up. I know you addressed it also on the prerecorded about some of the changes the SEC is proposing. Can you maybe talk a little bit about how you guys see your business evolving through that? Any potential spots that you’re looking closer at in terms of some of the reforms around 12b-1 fees or retail brokers sort of negotiating their own commissions, things like that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, I think it’s a little bit early. It’s just in the comment period, but I think it’s very consistent with what the industry felt was going to be proposed by the SEC. I think there’s a lot of positives to be taken from that. I think from
componenttext:
Yes. Again, I think it’s a little bit early. It’s just in the comment period, but I think it’s very consistent with what the industry felt was going to be proposed by the SEC. I think there’s a lot of positives to be taken from that. I think from a director perspective, it’s very positive to do away with what has been somewhat of a difficult process there. We also think it’s going to take a few years. The SEC has got a very full plate, so it could be years before any of this is resolved.
I think the real questions aren’t so much around the economics. I think those look reasonable from certainly our viewpoint. It’s really some of the operational challenges that we have to work through around, conversions and setting up new share classes with 25 basis point fees, the question around retirement shares. There are some open issues, but ones that we think we can work effectively with and hopefully through this comment period and come to a reasonable solution. I think, at the end of the day, the transparency for the investors settling just to 25, I think all of this is a positive for the future of the industry.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the net-net effect of this is that the C share will convert to an A share at a specific time. So that just means the advisor at that point moves from a higher ongoing fee to a 25 basis point fee, so that could shift how A shares are sold against C
componenttext:
I think the net-net effect of this is that the C share will convert to an A share at a specific time. So that just means the advisor at that point moves from a higher ongoing fee to a 25 basis point fee, so that could shift how A shares are sold against C. There is also the maximum charge, and a lot of that remains to be seen how that’s going to work versus the more traditional pay as you go. But again, the net effect is more around having conversion periods; if you’re a 30 basis points class share, that gets added to the front-end sales charge against the maximum charge, so at year 18 or whatever the breakeven point is that would have to convert to a 25 basis points new class.
So that’s where it gets I think a little bit confusing for a very small percentage of investors and where the industry needs to think about and quantify the impact versus the benefit. I think, overall, from an economic standpoint these are all pass-through numbers for us. It’s not really an income statement impact. It would lower the 12b number, but would also lower the expense side as well. So the net-net wouldn’t change.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think for the industry selling an A share with a high front-end load could just hurt the growth of the overall industry and you included?
componenttext: Do you think for the industry selling an A share with a high front-end load could just hurt the growth of the overall industry and you included?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you’ll still have the C share. It’s not going to change the A share. Just one of the proposals the broker/dealer can set a schedule, but it’s my understanding that we have to approve that schedule. What we would offer is just a straigh
componenttext: Well, I think you’ll still have the C share. It’s not going to change the A share. Just one of the proposals the broker/dealer can set a schedule, but it’s my understanding that we have to approve that schedule. What we would offer is just a straight NAV Class share or a 25 basis point B share Class and they would set their own schedule. So there is just a lot of work to be done on that, but certainly I don’t think the effect is going to be higher of higher front-end charge. That I think the push would be more on the lower side.

componenttext: I just want to go back to the cash balances on the balance sheet right now and the debt that was taken out during the quarter. So I guess you took out $900 million of debt and I know you said the Q is coming out. It seems it’s going to be close to $3.5 billion, and if it’s 50-50, you have about $1.8 billion in each, the U.S. and international. What do you guys think is the right level of cash in order to run those businesses? And then doesn’t even contemplate the investments that you have here. So, I am just trying to understand what is the true need for the debt that was taken out and how the capital really works for these businesses.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess in a couple of words simple answer would be financial flexibility and it’s something that surfaced well in the past and in fact allowed us to take advantage of pretty good interest rate environment. So if you remember back 2008, we had debt
componenttext: Yes. I guess in a couple of words simple answer would be financial flexibility and it’s something that surfaced well in the past and in fact allowed us to take advantage of pretty good interest rate environment. So if you remember back 2008, we had debt mature. We decided not to refinance that debt and interest rates; we didn’t like the interest rates at that time. We had a strong balance sheet; we were able to do that. In this environment, we saw an opportunity to give us some more financial flexibility and we took that. Some of the proceeds we used to pay down or to term out our commercial paper. In addition to that, we had a backstop facility that was up for renewal in June, and we just felt like the terms of that was uneconomical. So, basically it’s financial flexibility that allows to make these decisions without a gun to our head.

componenttext: Well, I think, it is important. I mean, I think it doesn’t mean you can’t be successful without having a presence, but we are in a relationship business, certainly, even with the gatekeepers and having a presence in people there to service those gatekeepers, whether it’s Europe and Asia is very important. And then if you build further out from that and have a local asset manager or retail presence, I think that just helps even more some of those relationships and people will view the firm differently. But that doesn’t mean you can’t be successful. Many firms have been very successful with a very limited presence or coming in and out. But we believe that the reason we’ve suddenly seen the spike up is a lot of the work that we did over the last decade in having a local presence and really working and building those relationships.
