headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Commentary for the Quarter Ended June 30, 2010. Please note that the financial results to be presented in this commentary are preliminary. Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources, Inc., whic
componenttext:
Welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Commentary for the Quarter Ended June 30, 2010. 
Please note that the financial results to be presented in this commentary are preliminary. Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources, Inc., which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. 
These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A sections of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K and 10-Q filings. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to the third quarter earnings commentary for 2010. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. We are pleased to report another very strong quarter despite challenging global markets. Overall, relative investment performance r
componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to the third quarter earnings commentary for 2010. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. We are pleased to report another very strong quarter despite challenging global markets. Overall, relative investment performance remains strong with over 80% of U.S. long-term assets ranked in the top two quartiles for three, five and 10-year periods. We're also pleased to see that short-term performance has strengthened in several areas. The combination of strong performance and the breadth of our product offerings translated into another record quarter for long-term net new flows of $18.2 billion.
International markets continued to be a key part of our growth story. In this quarter, we are recognized for selling our cross-border funds in more countries than any other asset manager. Additionally, as of May 31, we are the number one cross-border fund manager by long-term assets under management. All of this has helped produce three of our best quarters ever for flow, resulting in fiscal year-to-date increase in assets under management of $47.1 billion, despite $1.4 billion of net market depreciation.
Assets under management ended the quarter at $570.5 billion, a decrease of 3% from the prior quarter, primarily related to the sell-off in Global Equity Markets during the quarter, and that was partially offset by strong flows. 
Simple monthly average AUM increased 4% for the quarter to $583 billion. As a result, assets under management by investment objectives shifted towards Fixed Income at 40% of ending assets under management, Equity was 41% and Hybrid was 18% and our overall mix remains well balanced. 
The percentage of assets by sales region did not change much this quarter, but the quarter-over-quarter change in AUM by region illustrates the benefits of diversification as decreased assets from the United States and Canada were partially offset by increased assets from Europe and the Asia-Pacific regions.
$34.5 billion of market depreciation was the primary driver of the decrease in assets under management this quarter as equity markets posted double-digit decline. That was partially offset by another strong quarter of flows. Total net new flows were $18.8 billion, however, that includes $600 million of flows from cash management that were primarily related to FRI balance sheet activity, including the net issuance of debt. 
Total long-term net new flows, which excludes cash management, were $18.2 billion. U.S. long-term sales increased 2% to $25 billion, while redemptions increased 14%. Investor interest remains focused on fixed income, and the Templeton Global Bond Fund was our bestselling U.S. mutual fund, once again, attracting net new flows of $3.6 billion. While the Global Bond Fund continues to do exceptionally well, we're also seeing strong demand for our U.S. Government, our total return, our Tax Free Fixed Income Fund, as well as equity funds such as gold and precious metals and rising dividends.
In May, insurance companies typically make modifications to their fund lineup as part of their annual perspective changes. And this year, we are net beneficiaries on the order of $500 million this quarter as a result.
International long-term sales increased 18% to $26 billion and redemptions increased 16%. Net inflows to our cross-border SICAV range also remained strong with almost $13 billion of net new flows this quarter. The Templeton Global Bond Fund was our bestselling fund with over $6 billion in net new flows, but our Global Total Return, Emerging Market Bond, Asian Bond and Asian Growth Funds also saw a very strong flow.
Europe continues to be our top-selling region, led by Italy where we have been the number one selling asset manager in 2010. 
Turning to flows by investment objectives, equity flows turned positive due to the rebound of domestic equity that was primarily related to the insurance company flows I mentioned previously. Global equities saw a slight improvement in outflows, as the increase net redemptions we experienced in May were partially offset by a rebound in net new flows in June. Hybrid net new flows flowed to $100 million due to increased redemption. We're pleased to see our High Net Worth business continues to attract inflows, posting another strong quarter with over $200 million of net new flows.
Fixed income products, as I've already mentioned, had another strong quarter with $18 billion of net new flows, a modest increase from the last quarter. Cash management net inflows is $600 million, again as I previously mentioned were primarily due to FRI balance sheet activity.
Overall, long-term relative performance remained strong across the board. Equity one-year performance saw the most notable improvement, highlighted by a rebound of Mutual Series and strengthening Franklin Equity performance. 100% of Mutual Series assets were once again ranked in the top two quartile for the three, five and 10-year periods, and short-term performance improved with 38% of assets ranked in the top two quartile for the one-year period.
On the Fixed Income side, long-term performance remained strong as well, but we did see a decrease in the one-year ranking due to the federal tax-free fund that slipped into the third quartile or 53rd percentile. 
I'll now turn it over to Ken for operating results.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Happy to report another strong quarter of operating results for the company due to record net inflows and continued prudent expense management.  Operating income for the quarter was $521.6 million, which was a 13% increase from the prior qua
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Happy to report another strong quarter of operating results for the company due to record net inflows and continued prudent expense management.  Operating income for the quarter was $521.6 million, which was a 13% increase from the prior quarter. And net income was $360.5 million and earnings per share was $1.58. 
Slide 17 shows that investment management fees increased 10%, due to increased average assets under management, increased performance fees and carried interests as well as one additional day in the quarter. The effective fee rate for the quarter increased slightly to 60.7 basis points, excluding performance fees and carried interest of $33.5 million. Both underwriting distribution fees and expenses increased 7%, due to increased assets under management and commissionable growth sales. Shareholders servicing fees was $73 million, a 2% increase from the prior quarter, due to increased shareholder accounts.
During the quarter, Canada purged approximately 230,000 accounts as part of its annual cycle, and following quarter end, our U.S. transfer agent purged  approximately 3.2 million closed accounts. Other net revenue was $14.4 million, including a $3.1 million gain on residual interest in auto loan securitization.
Operating expenses increased 6% from the prior quarter, but there are a number of items worthy of additional explanation included in the expenses this quarter. Compensation and benefits increased 3% to $280 million, but included in this line is approximately $12.5 million of variable compensation related to the performance fees and carried interest earned during the quarter. 
Information system, technology and occupancy expenses increased 9% to $76 million and include a non-recurring charge of $6 million from the upfront loss on a sublease agreement.  And advertising and promotion was flat as increased advertising was offset by a decrease in promotional expenses.  We expect a seasonal uptick in advertising and promotion next quarter. 
Amortization of deferred sales commission increased to $50 million. The increase was primarily due to a non-recurring impairment of certain assets of $3.4 million. And other expenses increased $8.6 million, but included in this line are $7.4 million related to the carried interest earned this quarter as well as a $5 million charge from a legal settlement. 
With that said, some of the expenses are driven by the market on this line item. So it's reasonable to expect a slight increase in the run rate next quarter.
Excluding the increase in underwriting distribution expenses and the highlighted items, expenses were essentially flat from the quarter prior. Other expenses were $26.8 million, a decrease of $74 million from the prior quarter. Consolidated sponsored investment product losses were $14.7 million, representing the mark-to-market decrease of the securities held by those sponsored products and classified as trading on our balance sheet. The decrease is reasonable given the composition of our investments and the market declines during the quarter. Investment and other losses were $7.3 million, a decrease of $50 million from the prior quarter, due primarily to a change in net gains to net losses from equity method investments as well as lower mark-to-market gains and trading investments. Full details will be available in our Form 10-Q.
Interest expense increased to $4.8 million in the quarter as a result of the notes we issued in May. The effective tax rate for the quarter was 27.3%, due to a favorable tax ruling outside the U.S. We expect the tax rate for the full year to be between 29% and 30%, which implies a higher rate next quarter.  The operating margin for the quarter was 34% on a GAAP basis. 
On capital management, we repurchased 2.1 million shares this quarter, almost double last quarter's activity, decreasing ending shares outstanding to $225.4 million. The trailing 12-month payout issue was 107%, including the $3 special dividend paid in December, and we continue to manage our balance sheet opportunistically with respect to potential acquisitions, stock repurchases and dividends declared by our Board of Directors.
Total cash and investments were approximately $6.6 billion versus $5.7 billion on March 31, with a net increase primarily attributable to the increase in net debt during the quarter. 
And with that, I'll turn it back over to Greg.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ken. Before we wrap up, I'd like to quickly touch on some business highlights. In India, we were awarded Best On Shore Fund Manager by Asian Investor and the IACC's Indo-American Corporate Excellence Award for the Best U.S. Company in the Financia
componenttext:
Thanks, Ken. Before we wrap up, I'd like to quickly touch on some business highlights. In India, we were awarded Best On Shore Fund Manager by Asian Investor and the IACC's Indo-American Corporate Excellence Award for the Best U.S. Company in the Financial Sector. 
In Poland, we became the largest foreign asset manager. In Malaysia, we were appointed to manage our first Shariah equity mandate. And in Romania, we now expect to take over management of the almost $4 billion Romania Property Fund in this quarter. 
Last week the financial reform bill was signed into law, and while asset managers were not the focus, as a bank holding company, we are evaluating it's potential impact on our business. We're also evaluating those non-core banking services we provide to some of our high network of clients that cause us to be a bank holding company.
We have been closely following the SEC's dialogue on reforms for the 12b-1 rule, including it's most recent proposal. Our principal objective is to ensure that our fund shareholders will continue to receive professional advice and service in an efficient and cost-effective manner. We believe clarity and transparency around the use of 12b-1 fees is essential. And although the fees currently are fully disclosed, we will support efforts to help shareholders better understand our view. We do not currently expect these reforms to have a material impact.
As always, thank you for taking time to listen to this commentary. If you have any questions about the release or our comments, be sure to contact Investor Relations before the live call later today.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources' Earnings Conference Call for the quarter ended June 30, 2010. My name is Michael, and I will be your conference operator today. Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources' Earnings Conference Call for the quarter ended June 30, 2010. My name is Michael, and I will be your conference operator today. 
Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference call are preliminary. Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources, Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A sections of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K and 10-Q filings. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. As always, thanks for taking time today to join us this afternoon, and hopefully you had a chance to listen to the commentary that we made available this mornin
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. As always, thanks for taking time today to join us this afternoon, and hopefully you had a chance to listen to the commentary that we made available this morning. 
I'd like to recap a few of the highlights. This was another very strong quarter despite challenging  global market, and most importantly, investment performance remains strong with over 80% of our assets ranked in the top half of their peer groups for the three, five and 10-year period.
Long-term net inflows of $18.2 billion, which was a new record for us. And through three quarters of our fiscal year, we've had three of our four best quarters ever. 
I would now like to open it up for your questions. Thank you.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Roger Freeman with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Roger Freeman with Barclays Capital.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to the new -- the financial reform legislation and sort of bank holding company rules around limiting seed investments for funds managed, what are your thoughts around that given your structure and how you may respond to them?
componenttext: With respect to the new -- the financial reform legislation and sort of bank holding company rules around limiting seed investments for funds managed, what are your thoughts around that given your structure and how you may respond to them?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think like most, we've been very focused and we are a bank holding company and looking at what impact it may have. But I think like most, it's a little bit early to speculate. I think our feeling is that once it works its way through the process, which
componenttext: I think like most, we've been very focused and we are a bank holding company and looking at what impact it may have. But I think like most, it's a little bit early to speculate. I think our feeling is that once it works its way through the process, which could take a while, many studies to be done, many new rules to come out, we'll get some clarity around the issue. But I think as far as the issue of seeding funds, while that may look like that could be a problem, we don't anticipate that it should be a problem. But that risk is certainly out there. And I think, again, with our status, a holding company is something that we could change by stop offering  some non-core services. But there's also risk of being deemed a systemically important non-bank company. So that hangs out there as well. So we really just need a bit of time to get some clarity around these before we really can determine exactly how it will affect us. But I think we feel confident that issues like seed capital should be worked out.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: My second question, I guess around your Global Bond funds, the returns in the quarter, I guess it looks like the Templeton Global Bond is down 2.5% or so. Just looking again at the Barclays Global Index, which was about flat, can you talk at all about how
componenttext: My second question, I guess around your Global Bond funds, the returns in the quarter, I guess it looks like the Templeton Global Bond is down 2.5% or so. Just looking again at the Barclays Global Index, which was about flat, can you talk at all about how your Global Fund is maybe positioned relative to an index like that, either regionally or sort of within the old curve?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I can speak in general terms, but again, I'm not the PM, so I'd be careful in having me discuss how we're positioned because that could have changed from where I looked at it the last time. But we had been negative on the euro and positive on Asian
componenttext: Well, I can speak in general terms, but again, I'm not the PM, so I'd be careful in having me discuss how we're positioned because that could have changed from where I looked at it the last time. But we had been negative on the euro and positive on Asian currencies. And with the euro rebounding somewhat during that period, I'm sure that led to some underperformance. But as far as short-term performance goes, and especially in this kind of actively managed fund, there's going to be periods where you underperform the indices. And I think that our team is in a better position to address that. And again, I think the overall performance speaks for itself.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Katz with Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Katz with Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I have two questions. Number one, it looks like you had about almost a 30% organic growth rate outside the United States. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the dynamics behind that and maybe any sort of pipeline to the new quarter be in
componenttext: I have two questions. Number one, it looks like you had about almost a 30% organic growth rate outside the United States. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the dynamics behind that and maybe any sort of pipeline to the new quarter be interesting?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that kind of growth rate is going to be difficult to sustain. I mean, I think you had some unusual events, and certainly we talked about the euro and how that actually accelerated some of the Global Bond sales throughout Europe as people div
componenttext: Well, I think that kind of growth rate is going to be difficult to sustain. I mean, I think you had some unusual events, and certainly we talked about the euro and how that actually accelerated some of the Global Bond sales throughout Europe as people diversified away from the euro. So we were the net beneficiary. And I don't think that's a long-term sustainable trend. I do -- I think it's important to point out that we have seen very significant flows in other categories, in SICAV. Our Asian growth funds has been one of our top sellers there, as well as the Emerging Markets Fund. And also even within fixed income, many different types of bond funds. We had the Asian bond fund, which had over $1 billion in net sales, and it's really started to accelerate its growth. So as far as organic growth rates, I mean, those are hard to forecast. But I think it has been an unusual period with respect to the growth of Global Bonds. But I think we are getting the benefit of somewhat of the halo effect, when you have something as strong as the Global Bond category, that that's really helping our other funds as well as our equity funds. And for next quarter, I mean, we talked about the one large account that should fund. So, I mean,  obviously that's going to help when you just look at offshore organic growth rates. But again, that's a one-time event of $4 billion that should come in this quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: To the earlier question, just in terms I think investors' concern on the stock is the concentration of the flows. And it looks like this quarter was down to roughly half the volume versus about 60% last quarter. Is there anything you're doing at the whole
componenttext: To the earlier question, just in terms I think investors' concern on the stock is the concentration of the flows. And it looks like this quarter was down to roughly half the volume versus about 60% last quarter. Is there anything you're doing at the wholesale level to try to modify behavior?  Maybe it's payouts, incentives, I'm not sure exactly what, that would look to further diversify the platform.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's something that we are focused on. And again, the incentives for all of our salespeople have specific metrics around diversifying the book and diversifying it by advisor. And that's something that we recognize is a risk. But if you loo
componenttext: Well, I think that's something that we are focused on. And again, the incentives for all of our salespeople have specific metrics around diversifying the book and diversifying it by advisor. And that's something that we recognize is a risk. But if you looked at our marketing efforts today, certainly on the retail side with our 2020 Vision campaign, that's very much focused on trying to get investors to look at equities, because we think especially on the retail side, that probably too much money is moving into fixed income at these lower yields. We want to make sure that people recognize the risks there and are looking to equity. And I think the timing has been good with that campaign because we've seen our Franklin Equity Group continue to perform very well. And I think 75% of its assets are in the top quartile for the last year. So I think that you combine those two, and hopefully we'll get a little bit of momentum when things turn there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Fannon with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Fannon with Jefferies.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: You guys have talked previously about the kind of the gatekeepers, the consultants looking at the Global Bond as a new category. I'm wondering if you can kind of update on this in terms of some of the institutional, potential channels opening up or more o
componenttext: You guys have talked previously about the kind of the gatekeepers, the consultants looking at the Global Bond as a new category. I'm wondering if you can kind of update on this in terms of some of the institutional, potential channels opening up or more opportunities there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's certainly been the case. I mean, if you look at the category 10 years ago, it was very small. So even though it's grown quite a bit, it represents a relatively small position on the retail and as well as the institutional side. And we
componenttext: Well, I think that's certainly been the case. I mean, if you look at the category 10 years ago, it was very small. So even though it's grown quite a bit, it represents a relatively small position on the retail and as well as the institutional side. And we have, especially here in the States, a very dominant share of a growing asset class. And I think the other -- the good news is that it's a very large asset class when you're looking at sovereign debt, liquidity and the scale and the amount you can -- how big a fund can be in that category. So I think all of those are positive, and obviously the trend towards fixed income, and we're seeing that on the institutional side as well in more of the global Ag mandates and emerging market mandates. But that pipeline still looks very healthy.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Ken, on the number side, just heading into your kind of fiscal year end for next quarter, should there be any seasonality to the comp or the comp ratios as we think about a catch up given the strength in sales and your guys' pretty strong growth
componenttext: And then, Ken, on the number side, just heading into your kind of fiscal year end for next quarter, should there be any seasonality to the comp or the comp ratios as we think about a catch up given the strength in sales and your guys' pretty strong growth rates?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure.  There was that nonrecurring item this quarter of $12.5 million, and I guess that implies, from my point of view, a run rate that is probably a little bit on the low side. I think -- but, of course, depending on revenue, and with the markets di
componenttext: Yes, sure.  There was that nonrecurring item this quarter of $12.5 million, and I guess that implies, from my point of view, a run rate that is probably a little bit on the low side. I think -- but, of course, depending on revenue, and with the markets dipping in May, you're might see a little bit of a drop in revenue. But all that said, I think we'll see a little bit of an upward pressure on the top line. Not too much, but just a little.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, can you just maybe give us your thoughts on kind of retail investor sentiment more broadly? It seems like we're in somewhat of a holding period where retail investors just aren't really coming back into equities for the time being. Do you get the se
componenttext: Greg, can you just maybe give us your thoughts on kind of retail investor sentiment more broadly? It seems like we're in somewhat of a holding period where retail investors just aren't really coming back into equities for the time being. Do you get the sense that this could be kind of a multi-year process? Or what do you think we need to see in order to maybe speed that process up?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you probably know the answer. I mean, it's really what happens with the market. And I think that investor was coming back and flows were improving. But after the flash crash and then some of the debt problems over the quarter, retail investo
componenttext: Well, I think you probably know the answer. I mean, it's really what happens with the market. And I think that investor was coming back and flows were improving. But after the flash crash and then some of the debt problems over the quarter, retail investor tends to retreat. And it's not so much redemption as it is they just stop putting new monies in so the net numbers tend to look a lot worse than you would think. So for us, we're going to keep talking about equities. We're going to keep pushing our 2020 Vision campaign. And I think they will come back. But it's a function of what the economy does, what confidence levels are out there. And right now, it's just not that very high. I think there is still good flows going into more packaged products. Variable annuities, 401(K) are still relatively positive. But it's just the discretionary equity additions to portfolios that I think are under the most stress.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe can you just give us an update on activity levels on the institutional side more broadly? And then just the mandate that sets a fund this quarter. What type of strategy is that?
componenttext: And then maybe can you just give us an update on activity levels on the institutional side more broadly? And then just the mandate that sets a fund this quarter. What type of strategy is that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, first of all, with regards to just the pipeline, and I don't think there's been any real shift. It's still global fixed income, global Ag, the emerging market, debt and global equities for us, and occasionally some other classes, but that w
componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, with regards to just the pipeline, and I don't think there's been any real shift. It's still global fixed income, global Ag, the emerging market, debt and global equities for us, and occasionally some other classes, but that would represent the bulk. And we're still seeing very strong activity there. The dual fund was a multi-year effort for us that had to go through some government approvals to move the monies over to an outside manager. That has taken place, so we hope to have that $4 billion account in. And as far as fees go, I would just say that, one, we don't disclose specific fees, but it's something where you would expect an institutional global mandate. And when you say, "What does it look like?" It doesn't look like anything because it's a closed-end fund, Romanian Securities. And that is a new category for us, certainly. We have to add people, and we just opened up the office in Bucharest here in the last few weeks.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: First, performance to you this quarter, was that mostly Darby? And if so, what are the assets that are generating those performance fees? I think they're like $2.3 billion in your K. How big are they today?
componenttext: First, performance to you this quarter, was that mostly Darby? And if so, what are the assets that are generating those performance fees? I think they're like $2.3 billion in your K. How big are they today?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: They were a split between Darby and some of our Emerging Markets products. Still the performance fees as a percentage of assets are very small. And these things are hard to predict. I guess the concentration of the investments might have been more skewed
componenttext: They were a split between Darby and some of our Emerging Markets products. Still the performance fees as a percentage of assets are very small. And these things are hard to predict. I guess the concentration of the investments might have been more skewed toward Latin America. I don't think performance fees have been a material part of our revenue story, and I don't expect they will be in the near future.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And what's the asset base?
componenttext: And what's the asset base?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, like I say, it was both Darby and Emerging Markets. And I think it's about like less than 1%, 1% or 2%, of AUM.
componenttext: Well, like I say, it was both Darby and Emerging Markets. And I think it's about like less than 1%, 1% or 2%, of AUM.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And, then secondly, on Canada. Canada's been in redemption, I think, each and every month this year. And it seems like in the Canadian markets, the dynamic funds and fidelity are taking huge share. So what's going on with the Franklin business in Canada,
componenttext: And, then secondly, on Canada. Canada's been in redemption, I think, each and every month this year. And it seems like in the Canadian markets, the dynamic funds and fidelity are taking huge share. So what's going on with the Franklin business in Canada, and what is it going to take to kind of turn that business around?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you're right. It has been a very challenging market, especially for any firm that has global equity funds in that category. The Canadian market's been very strong as you'd expect with the strength in commodities. That willing drives that mar
componenttext: Well, I think you're right. It has been a very challenging market, especially for any firm that has global equity funds in that category. The Canadian market's been very strong as you'd expect with the strength in commodities. That willing drives that market, so most of the monies are going into domestic mandates. For us, we diversified away from the flagship Templeton Growth Fund in that market and have been very successful with a more of an allocation story up there, and that continues to do very well. And the other issue was the concentration and distribution. There's more distribution happening through banks and captive sales forces, and I think that's something that any outside manager needs to look at in the future. But it's just been harder and harder for the independent manager. And I think that goes against the trend we see in the rest of the world.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Lee with KBW [Keefe, Bruyette, & Woods].
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Lee with KBW [Keefe, Bruyette, & Woods].

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is heading -- if I look back, I think back a couple of quarters, markets were better all around. And I think the general sense is that you guys have started to kind of loosen the reigns a little bit on investment spend, I mean, not drama
componenttext: My first question is heading -- if I look back, I think back a couple of quarters, markets were better all around. And I think the general sense is that you guys have started to kind of loosen the reigns a little bit on investment spend, I mean, not dramatically, but kind of starting to spend a little bit more money on new initiatives than maybe you had in the year or so prior. Given where we were and what the markets did the last quarter and where we are right now, how do you -- what's kind of your current view from an expense perspective? Is there kind of a backlog of projects you need to get to? And with your pretty strong volumes, is that kind of keeping the pressure on having to spend on infrastructure?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Robert, this is Ken. So we are going through the budget process right now, and I wouldn't characterize it as a tremendous backlog of requests for spend. So we clearly want to leverage the success that we have and the opportunities that we're seeing from t
componenttext: Robert, this is Ken. So we are going through the budget process right now, and I wouldn't characterize it as a tremendous backlog of requests for spend. So we clearly want to leverage the success that we have and the opportunities that we're seeing from those successes, and we're committed to do that. I think a lot of the bulk of the expense requests are to invest in operations outside the U.S. in portfolio and distribution. And when we get those requests, they usually come with at least some objective of generating revenue. So if your question is about margin compression  or expansion, I think we try to take a balanced approach, and we just prioritize the investments based on what we think the potential payback is.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: If you look through your various managers, I'm thinking mainly of Darby, and I guess it's Franklin Real Estate Advisors, I guess they're predominantly where you would have different alternative strategies in a classic definition. As you look into the inst
componenttext: If you look through your various managers, I'm thinking mainly of Darby, and I guess it's Franklin Real Estate Advisors, I guess they're predominantly where you would have different alternative strategies in a classic definition. As you look into the institutional world, I mean, there's certainly more dollars kind of being targeted towards alternative strategies broadly, I think, around the world, I mean, how do you -- do you think those are big enough platforms to really kind of grow meaningfully? Or do you think that just broadly within alternatives, is that an area where you'd want to try to increase focus, whether it's through acquisitions, team liftouts, kind of what are your thoughts there?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we are watching the -- certainly institutional market and where our fees are going, and the increased allocation towards alternatives continue as the expected returns on traditional loan only equities and fixed income have continued to decli
componenttext: Well, I think we are watching the -- certainly institutional market and where our fees are going, and the increased allocation towards alternatives continue as the expected returns on traditional loan only equities and fixed income have continued to decline, and you have to meet that liability there. So we are very aware of that. And as we stated before, we have to fit in an alternatives manager that makes sense within our given structure, and also with the right kind of economic incentives to maintain a transition, whether it's an acquisition or a partial ownership. And something that we are doing today that's a little bit different than what we've done in the past is to take minority stakes.  That hasn't been so much the case now, but something we're open to doing with emerging managers in the alternative space rather than just going in and acquiring it outright, but taking minority stake,  working with them and increasing that stake from there. So I think that's just a recognition of it.  It's a little bit different business for us, and it doesn't necessarily fit in, in the more traditional acquisition of a mutual fund company. We have more activity there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Carrier with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Carrier with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just in the International Fixed Income bucket, I just wanted to try to get a little bit more clarity or granularity. We all focus on the Global Bond Fund, but just what other products are in that mix that are benefiting as well? And then from a flow persp
componenttext: Just in the International Fixed Income bucket, I just wanted to try to get a little bit more clarity or granularity. We all focus on the Global Bond Fund, but just what other products are in that mix that are benefiting as well? And then from a flow perspective, any granularity on where it's coming from, so whether it's retail, institutional, U.S., non-U.S.  And then knowing those investors, just if that product or that new asset class is -- starts to lose its luster, where will they head in the guarded position to take advantage of that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: That's some of the point I made earlier about looking at the flows and other categories for us within fixed income. And the global total return, which is a SICAV fund, had $2.7 billion. It's a global Ag.  It's a traditional sovereign-plus corporate, and t
componenttext: That's some of the point I made earlier about looking at the flows and other categories for us within fixed income. And the global total return, which is a SICAV fund, had $2.7 billion. It's a global Ag.  It's a traditional sovereign-plus corporate, and that had $2.7 billion of net inflows versus $2.2 billion in the prior quarter within our SICAV lineup. Our Emerging Market Bond Fund had $1 billion in net sales versus $700 million in the prior quarter. And the Asian Bond Fund on a $1 billion base had over $1 billion in net sales for the net quarter to end up at $2.2 billion base. So those are some other funds that are doing extremely well. And as far as the retail, institutional, the U.S. is going to be primarily retail, using the fund, almost all retail. And the U.S. is going to be -- outside the U.S. is going to be a little bit of both, with a lot of those dollars coming from Europe and places like Switzerland in particular.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one question on the cash. You raised the debt so now you have even more cash. But -- and you did the buybacks, and I think historically you guys always point out whether it's with the special dividend and buybacks, or current dividends. It's
componenttext: And then just one question on the cash. You raised the debt so now you have even more cash. But -- and you did the buybacks, and I think historically you guys always point out whether it's with the special dividend and buybacks, or current dividends. It's a big payout. When you look at the portion that's in the U.S. versus outside the U.S., just an update on that. But then more importantly, how do you gauge that decision on bringing more cash into the U.S., paying taxes, wait for a tax holiday? What goes through your mind in terms of when you make that decision?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll file the Q shortly and give you the exact figure for offshore cash, but I think after the debt raised, we're close back to that 50/50. So in terms of our repatriation policy and all that, the International area is our area of growth. And so th
componenttext: Well, we'll file the Q shortly and give you the exact figure for offshore cash, but I think after the debt raised, we're close back to that 50/50. So in terms of our repatriation policy and all that, the International area is our area of growth. And so the basic advice is to leave the money there and invest it in the foreign operations, because that's where we're seeing a lot of growth. And then the overall overwriting concept is to return to shareholders. And we've kind of been fairly consistent in the percentages of our payout ratio, what percentage of net income we return to shareholders with dividends and share repurchases. And so that's really what we're looking at. And I think we have plenty of financial flexibility to continue -- continuing that history of being shareholder friendly, and when that gets to a point where it's jeopardized, I think that we'll have to revisit our situation.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Cynthia Mayer with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Cynthia Mayer with Bank of America.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: I'm wondering if you could give us on a little color on which strategies won the net $500 million in mandates from insurance companies in May?  And also, some others in the industry have been saying that insurance companies are moving away from active managers because they find it hard to hedge. Did you find that dynamic at play all in discussions for the company?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I read that article as well, and I didn't see or hear about any redemptions that were made for that reason. But certainly, I think that's something to be aware of. The big win for us was the $790 million small cap fund that came in over the quarter. And n
componenttext: I read that article as well, and I didn't see or hear about any redemptions that were made for that reason. But certainly, I think that's something to be aware of. The big win for us was the $790 million small cap fund that came in over the quarter. And no real -- outside of that, it's Mutual Series. It's Templeton. It really is fairly well diversified within the annuity channel.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: Why is the U.S. purge so much higher this year, like 3 million account versus 2 million last year?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: That's our closed accounts that we keep for a year, and then purge them once a year. So closed accounts probably for increased redemptions last year.
componenttext: That's our closed accounts that we keep for a year, and then purge them once a year. So closed accounts probably for increased redemptions last year.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Oh, I see, because it sort of trails.
componenttext: Oh, I see, because it sort of trails.

componenttext: It's a year lag.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Marc Irizarry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Marc Irizarry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, the non-U.S. sales continue to be very impressive. And I'm sure you're continuing to gain momentum in a lot of different regions out there. Can you talk about the regions where you're seeing the most momentum? And then also, how does the strategy of
componenttext: Greg, the non-U.S. sales continue to be very impressive. And I'm sure you're continuing to gain momentum in a lot of different regions out there. Can you talk about the regions where you're seeing the most momentum? And then also, how does the strategy of local -- of M&A of local managers sort of fit into where you ultimately can see your market share overseas?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it really hasn't changed. I mean, we think that having a local manager, if you're going to develop a strong presence in a given retail market and they have a demand for local management, we want to be there in that market. I mean, I don't th
componenttext: Well, I think it really hasn't changed. I mean, we think that having a local manager, if you're going to develop a strong presence in a given retail market and they have a demand for local management, we want to be there in that market. I mean, I don't think that's changed. I just think you have an unusual period right now, and with Southern Europe and Italy, Spain, with the euro that have accelerated fixed income sales. And I think generally you can make the statement that that's probably going to be less sticky than traditional-type money because the nature of what people are doing, if the euro goes the other way, that could move. So I think you have to be sensitive to that. But I think our strategy of continuing to develop local asset managers hasn't changed at all. I mean, there's only a couple of markets that you would say have addressable retail markets that we're not in right now, and those are the ones that we're certainly looking at.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just can you talk a bit about the taxable fixed income growth? Obviously the growth sales accelerated, but so did the redemption rate. Can you speak a little bit about the dynamic there just in taxable fixed income? And obviously, on the sales si
componenttext: And then just can you talk a bit about the taxable fixed income growth? Obviously the growth sales accelerated, but so did the redemption rate. Can you speak a little bit about the dynamic there just in taxable fixed income? And obviously, on the sales side it seemed like maybe the euro was accelerating some non-U.S. sales? But what happened in terms of redemptions in the quarter?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think they moved up a little bit, but -- on the fixed income side. But nothing -- I don't think it was a dramatic change. And it is interesting when growth sales increased that redemptions tend to increase. And I've never understood that, an
componenttext: Well, I don't think they moved up a little bit, but -- on the fixed income side. But nothing -- I don't think it was a dramatic change. And it is interesting when growth sales increased that redemptions tend to increase. And I've never understood that, and I've been looking at retail sales for a long time, that you would expect them to stay stable when things are increasing, but they tend to move up on, just for whatever reason for the activity. So I don't have a good answer on why taxable fixed would have increased the redemption activity over the period. But I can say it wasn't really -- it wasn't really much.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Spahr with CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Spahr with CLSA.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: My question is related to how your teams are structured particularly in the global fixed income side. I get questions from my clients on, like say, key person risk in particular funds. I just want to know how your teams are structured, and if the Global B
componenttext: My question is related to how your teams are structured particularly in the global fixed income side. I get questions from my clients on, like say, key person risk in particular funds. I just want to know how your teams are structured, and if the Global Bond Fund and the Global Total Return Fund are the same management team.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: They are not for those two examples. But the Global Fixed is headed up specifically by Dr. Hasenstab who obviously has a very high profile throughout really the world on both institutional and retail, and a team that we continue to build underneath him. S
componenttext: They are not for those two examples. But the Global Fixed is headed up specifically by Dr. Hasenstab who obviously has a very high profile throughout really the world on both institutional and retail, and a team that we continue to build underneath him. So I think our feeling is that we -- stars get developed in this industry. It's a risk we know. And we want to make sure that we have a deep bench and a consistent process that we can repeat. But that's certainly always a risk, but we're well aware of that risk. And then within the other -- all of the Taxable Fixed is a separate team as well. And the munis are a separate team. It's all headed up by one person who runs Fixed Income, but we have four or five different CIOs within Fixed Income for the different strategies, and Michael Hasenstab's one of those with the Global Bonds.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you touched on this earlier, just getting traction on the local funds, particularly on the equity side, can you just give a sense of like when some of the strategies you guys can employ, like say whether it's in India or other Asian markets, or ev
componenttext: I think you touched on this earlier, just getting traction on the local funds, particularly on the equity side, can you just give a sense of like when some of the strategies you guys can employ, like say whether it's in India or other Asian markets, or even European markets?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that each market you can look at. I mean, the local managers have done very well this year. But we're not talking about it because I think as a percentage of the total numbers, it looks fairly small. I mean, India has been an example for us
componenttext: Well, I think that each market you can look at. I mean, the local managers have done very well this year. But we're not talking about it because I think as a percentage of the total numbers, it looks fairly small. I mean, India has been an example for us where we've increased market share considerably, and that's been a real success story here where we have lost some shares over the last few years, and that's on the back of a very strong performance in that local market. But those markets are going to take time. You're just not going to get the kind of momentum you can get from developed markets where all of a sudden your mix is in favor of where the market is going. Certainly our mix has been in the right spot for a lot of the more developed markets. But that doesn't change our thinking on the other Asian, India, the other markets that are just going to take a longer time to develop.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Douglas Sipkin with Ticonderoga.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Douglas Sipkin with Ticonderoga.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to expand a little bit on marketing expense. I know you guys provided a little bit of detail on the pre-recorded call. But some of your competitors talked about spending more now. I mean, are you guys feeling more pressure that you are going t
componenttext: Just wanted to expand a little bit on marketing expense. I know you guys provided a little bit of detail on the pre-recorded call. But some of your competitors talked about spending more now. I mean, are you guys feeling more pressure that you are going to need to go above and beyond what you've been doing? I know you've been sort of leading the pack on spending on the marketing side. Or do you feel pretty comfortable with where you're trending, and even though it sounds like comps are moving up, you don't feel like you need to change all that much?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think we need to make any dramatic change to our strategy. I've been saying for a couple of quarters that we have planned and continue to increase advertising spend, and I think that trend will continue. We've offset a little bit this quarter by r
componenttext: I don't think we need to make any dramatic change to our strategy. I've been saying for a couple of quarters that we have planned and continue to increase advertising spend, and I think that trend will continue. We've offset a little bit this quarter by reduced promotion, but certainly the advertising spend was up this quarter. And I expect that to increase next quarter or two. Not a lot, but a little bit. And like I said, no real change in our strategy. It's just we made commitments, and we'll probably see them come through in future quarters.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I know you addressed it also in the pre-recorded about some of the changes the SEC is proposing. Can you maybe talk a little bit about how you guys see your business evolving through that? And any potential spots that you're looking closer at in terms of
componenttext: I know you addressed it also in the pre-recorded about some of the changes the SEC is proposing. Can you maybe talk a little bit about how you guys see your business evolving through that? And any potential spots that you're looking closer at in terms of some of the reforms around 12b-1 fees or retail brokers sort of negotiating their own commission, things like that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, I think it's a little bit early. It's just in the comment period. But I think it's very consistent with what the industry felt was going to be proposed by the SEC. And I think there's a lot of positives to be taken from that. I think from a directo
componenttext: Again, I think it's a little bit early. It's just in the comment period. But I think it's very consistent with what the industry felt was going to be proposed by the SEC. And I think there's a lot of positives to be taken from that. I think from a director perspective, it's very positive to do away with what has been somewhat of a difficult process there. We also think it's going to take a few years. The SEC has got a very full plate, so it could be years before any of this is resolved. And I think the real questions aren't so much around the economics. I think those look reasonable, from certainly our viewpoint. It's really some of the operational challenges that we have to work through around conversions and setting up new share classes with 25 basis points fees, the question around retirement shares. There's some open issues, but ones that we think we can work effectively with and hopefully through this comment period and come to reasonable solution. But I think at the end of the day, the transparency for the investors settling this to 25, I think all of this is just positive for the future of the industry.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Alan Straus with Omega.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alan Straus with Omega.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the 12b-1 one issue. Do you think -- you have a lot of money that's being passed through your income statement. Where do you think a lot of that money is going to be made up, or is the brokerages just going to make less money?
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the 12b-1 one issue. Do you think -- you have a lot of money that's being passed through your income statement. Where do you think a lot of that money is going to be made up, or is the brokerages just going to make less money?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the net effect of this is that the C-share will convert to an A-share at a specific time. So that just means the advisor at that point moves from a higher ongoing fee to a 25 basis point fee. So that could shift how his shares are sold agains
componenttext: Yes, I think the net effect of this is that the C-share will convert to an A-share at a specific time. So that just means the advisor at that point moves from a higher ongoing fee to a 25 basis point fee. So that could shift how his shares are sold against fee. But there's also the maximum charge, and a lot of that remains to be seen how that's going to work versus the more traditional pay as you go. But again, the net effect is more around having conversion periods. If you have a 30 basis point class share, that gets added to the front end sales charge against the maximum charge. So at year 18, or whatever the breakeven point is, that would have to convert to a 25 basis point new class. So that's where it gets, I think, a little bit confusing for a very small percentage of investors, and where the industry needs to think about and quantify the impact versus the benefit. But I think overall from an economic standpoint, these are all pass-through numbers for us. It's not really an income statement impact. It would lower the 12b number, but it would also lower the expense side as well. So the net-net wouldn't change.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think for the industries selling in Asia with a high front-end load could just hurt the growth of the overall industry, and you included?
componenttext: Do you think for the industries selling in Asia with a high front-end load could just hurt the growth of the overall industry, and you included?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you'll still have the C-shares. It's not going to change the A-share. It's just one of the proposals. The broker-dealer can set a schedule. But it's my understanding that we have to approve that schedule, where we'd offer just a straight any
componenttext: Well, I think you'll still have the C-shares. It's not going to change the A-share. It's just one of the proposals. The broker-dealer can set a schedule. But it's my understanding that we have to approve that schedule, where we'd offer just a straight any B-class share or a 25 basis point B-share class and they would set their own schedule. So there's just a lot of work to be done on that, but certainly I don't think the effect is going to be a higher front-end charge. I think the push would be more on the lower side.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Roger Smith with Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Roger Smith with Macquarie.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back to that cash balances on the balance sheet right now and the debt that was taken out during the quarter. So I guess, you took out $900 million of debt. And my guess is that the cash, and I know you said the Q is coming out soon, i
componenttext: I just wanted to go back to that cash balances on the balance sheet right now and the debt that was taken out during the quarter. So I guess, you took out $900 million of debt. And my guess is that the cash, and I know you said the Q is coming out soon, it's going to be close to $3.5 billion. And if it's 50-50, you have about $1.8 billion in each the U.S. and International. What do you guys think is the right level of cash in order to run those businesses? And then that doesn't even contemplate the investments that you have here. So I'm just trying to understand what is the true need for the debt that was taken out and how the capital really works for these businesses?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess in a couple of words, simple answer would be financial flexibility. And it's something that served us well in the past. And in fact, a lot to take advantage of a pretty good interest rate environment. So if you remember back 2008, we had debt matu
componenttext: I guess in a couple of words, simple answer would be financial flexibility. And it's something that served us well in the past. And in fact, a lot to take advantage of a pretty good interest rate environment. So if you remember back 2008, we had debt mature. We decided not to refinance that debt.  Interest rates -- we liked the interest rates at that time. We had a strong balance sheet. We were able to do that. In this environment, we saw an opportunity to give us a more financial flexibility and we took that. And we did -- some of the proceeds we used to term out our commercial paper. And in addition to that, we had a back stop facility that was up for renewal in June, and we just felt like the terms of that were uneconomical. So basically financial flexibility allowed us to make these decisions without a gun to our head.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Roger Freeman with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Roger Freeman with Barclays Capital.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Going back to Darby for a second. Realizing a small percentage -- I just want to just sort of understand given that thing obviously does carry when you realize investment gains. I mean, if this is a, call it, $2 billion AUM business, which from the K it l
componenttext: Going back to Darby for a second. Realizing a small percentage -- I just want to just sort of understand given that thing obviously does carry when you realize investment gains. I mean, if this is a, call it, $2 billion AUM business, which from the K it looks like it's probably something in that range, can you think about this over time that you generate at 2x multiple investor capital, which that should be low for private equity. And is 20% carry the right way to think about that? I mean, I could generate $400 million in revenue over time?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a classic private equity. It's specialties. It's mezzanine debt.  It's emerging markets. And I think that we'll see more carried interest from Darby, because some of those funds are maturing and some of the investments are maturing. But I reall
componenttext: Well, it's a classic private equity. It's specialties. It's mezzanine debt.  It's emerging markets. And I think that we'll see more carried interest from Darby, because some of those funds are maturing and some of the investments are maturing. But I really don't expect it to be recurring in the short term. So when you're -- if you're talking about five years, yes, maybe. But in the next year or two, I don't expect it to be a significant or a material part of revenue.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: How seasoned are the portfolios there? What's the average life of an investment right now? So we can kind of think about that realization cycle that may be coming down the road?
componenttext: How seasoned are the portfolios there? What's the average life of an investment right now? So we can kind of think about that realization cycle that may be coming down the road?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say it's about in the seven to 10 year horizon from its inception. And some of those funds did start, or one or two of them started, in the late '90s. And we're seeing some of the benefits from that. But a lot of them also were launched in the las
componenttext: I would say it's about in the seven to 10 year horizon from its inception. And some of those funds did start, or one or two of them started, in the late '90s. And we're seeing some of the benefits from that. But a lot of them also were launched in the last four or five years.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And just looking, again, at sort of the structure of the payout, and if you look at sort of the comp and then the other expense, which it sounds like it's tied to comp, I mean, it kind of looks like it's a 60% payout on the carry. It seems kind of high fo
componenttext: And just looking, again, at sort of the structure of the payout, and if you look at sort of the comp and then the other expense, which it sounds like it's tied to comp, I mean, it kind of looks like it's a 60% payout on the carry. It seems kind of high for even private equity. Is that a fair calculation?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it wasn't all private equity. As I mentioned, part of it was Emerging Markets, some of our products in Emerging Markets. I thought it was more like 50%.
componenttext: Yes, it wasn't all private equity. As I mentioned, part of it was Emerging Markets, some of our products in Emerging Markets. I thought it was more like 50%.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just the performance season and the other stuff, is that relative? Are those other funds on a relative basis a benchmark or is it absolute returns? The performance fees on your other funds, so aside from Darby, do those tend to be relative to som
componenttext: And then just the performance season and the other stuff, is that relative? Are those other funds on a relative basis a benchmark or is it absolute returns? The performance fees on your other funds, so aside from Darby, do those tend to be relative to some benchmark on the returns or absolute? Because it's interesting because there was a higher amount of performance this quarter than last given that markets were down.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's true. But some of the investments, I think, were concentrated in Latin America and they performed a little bit better.  I think that's where that's...
componenttext: Yes, that's true. But some of the investments, I think, were concentrated in Latin America and they performed a little bit better.  I think that's where that's...

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The impairment of the first sales commissions, can you just talk about the process for approaching that? Do you do that every quarter? Or is it over some period of time so you sort of capture a time frame in there?
componenttext: The impairment of the first sales commissions, can you just talk about the process for approaching that? Do you do that every quarter? Or is it over some period of time so you sort of capture a time frame in there?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do it every quarter. And the thing that was  driving that this quarter was just the change in our assumptions, particularly related to redemption rates, which coming through the last global financial crisis, we were using some pretty high redempti
componenttext: Yes, we do it every quarter. And the thing that was  driving that this quarter was just the change in our assumptions, particularly related to redemption rates, which coming through the last global financial crisis, we were using some pretty high redemption rates so we lowered them to a more normal level?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just thoughts around the tax refunds. The net flow there has slowed, and they have for the industry as well. Is your view that that's primarily just a function of concerns around muni finances, and does that have to abate before you sort of see more broad
componenttext: Just thoughts around the tax refunds. The net flow there has slowed, and they have for the industry as well. Is your view that that's primarily just a function of concerns around muni finances, and does that have to abate before you sort of see more broad-based flows in the munis?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's true. I think there's -- obviously, there's been a lot of articles, a lot of noise, around state budgets, and I think that's going to continue to be a headwind for munis. And also yields have gotten down there pretty low as well. So I think
componenttext: I think that's true. I think there's -- obviously, there's been a lot of articles, a lot of noise, around state budgets, and I think that's going to continue to be a headwind for munis. And also yields have gotten down there pretty low as well. So I think those are all contributing to the net flow number dropping. But I still think it's healthy and it's positive, and despite some of these headwinds, we are seeing positive net sales. So I think that's good. But you're right, they have slowed.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: And your final question will come from the line of Bill Katz with Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the leverage of the non-U.S. business, how important is it having on the ground presence in terms of gaining market share relative to some of the competition that might be based outside of the region trying to tap into the market to gai
componenttext: Just going back to the leverage of the non-U.S. business, how important is it having on the ground presence in terms of gaining market share relative to some of the competition that might be based outside of the region trying to tap into the market to gain some share?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it is important. I mean, I think it doesn't mean you can't be successful without having a presence. But we're in a relationship business certainly, even with gatekeepers and having a presence and people there to service those gatekeepers, wh
componenttext: Well, I think it is important. I mean, I think it doesn't mean you can't be successful without having a presence. But we're in a relationship business certainly, even with gatekeepers and having a presence and people there to service those gatekeepers, whether it's Europe and Asia is very important. And then if you build further out from that and have a local asset manager or a retail presence, I think that just helps even more cement some of those relationships, and people will view the firm differently. But that doesn't mean you can't be successful, and many firms have been very successful with a very limited presence or coming in and out. But we believe that the reason we've suddenly seen this spike up is a lot of the work that we did over the last decade in having a local presence and really working and building those relationships.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: On the capital structure of the company, can you just sort of help us understand how you think about buyback versus carrying a little leverage here. I just don't understand why you need it all for the debt given both your existing level of liquidity and your sizable free cash flow versus buyback?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: Well, I think you saw we did increase the buybacks this quarter. Buybacks are always attractive to us, and I think we'll continue to do that. You can see that we took advantage of a market debt. And so again, it's just basically financial flexibility to take advantage of those situations.

componenttext:
Welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Commentary for the Quarter Ended September 30, 2010. Please note that the financial results to be presented in this commentary are preliminary. Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources, Inc., which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements.
