headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question is just in terms of the very strong growth you're seeing in the non-U.S., can you walk through a little bit about maybe geographically, break it down between Europe, Asia, elsewhere and maybe by product, the way you see in the greatest le
componenttext: Second question is just in terms of the very strong growth you're seeing in the non-U.S., can you walk through a little bit about maybe geographically, break it down between Europe, Asia, elsewhere and maybe by product, the way you see in the greatest leverage?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The two areas we've talked a bit in the past, I mean the global bond fund, has been very successful throughout Europe, and especially in Italy over the past year. We've got probably three or four bond funds, Templeton Global, total return, emerging marke
componenttext: The two areas we've talked a bit in the past, I mean the global bond fund, has been very successful throughout Europe, and especially in Italy over the past year. We've got probably three or four bond funds, Templeton Global, total return, emerging markets bond fund and then, Asian bond fund as well. That's done extremely well in Europe. The Asia growth fund is now our top-selling fund on the equity side. And that's run by Dr. Mobius of the Emerging Markets group and has had excellent performance. So really, I don't have the breakdown in front of me between how much of that is coming from Europe versus Asia. But I think the real big movers for us have been in Europe this year as far as net inflows and in Taiwan as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just first, equity mutual fund net flows across the industry have turned positive more recently in aggregate following kind of about six months of kind of persistent outflows. And do you feel like we could be in an inflection point? Or do you think it's
componenttext: Just first, equity mutual fund net flows across the industry have turned positive more recently in aggregate following kind of about six months of kind of persistent outflows. And do you feel like we could be in an inflection point? Or do you think it's going to take a bit more time before equity flows really start to meaningfully reaccelerate? And then, it seems like the trends are a bit different as you look at overseas investors. So any additional color there?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's been the question for a while now is when does this turnaround. And obviously a very strong quarter and that's going to help investors confidence move back into equities. But like most of the industry, I mean, we haven't seen a big s
componenttext: Well, I think that's been the question for a while now is when does this turnaround. And obviously a very strong quarter and that's going to help investors confidence move back into equities. But like most of the industry, I mean, we haven't seen a big swing. And we've seen some movements in some of our funds, especially with the rising dividend fund. For us, those type of equity income funds are very popular in this kind of environment. But I just don't think we're seeing a big turn around in investor confidence yet. But certainly, in a quarter like we just had will help that. But I do think it's going to take a while, and I think the kind of flows that we have seen over the last six months will continue in the near term, as far as fixed income versus equities.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the institutional channel, any kind of noticeable changes in either activity levels? Or shifts in terms of which strategies might be in demand? Is it still kind of global equities, global fixed income?
componenttext: And then in terms of the institutional channel, any kind of noticeable changes in either activity levels? Or shifts in terms of which strategies might be in demand? Is it still kind of global equities, global fixed income?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Exactly. And I was just looking down the list and it's probably 95%, 90% of the search activity that we are involved in is in the global fixed and global equity area.
componenttext: Exactly. And I was just looking down the list and it's probably 95%, 90% of the search activity that we are involved in is in the global fixed and global equity area.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Credit Suisse.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the international sales topic. And maybe to ask it in a different way is on your SICAV product, what is the average asset-based distribution expense? And also, are there any distribution revenues, or did they all flow through manageme
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the international sales topic. And maybe to ask it in a different way is on your SICAV product, what is the average asset-based distribution expense? And also, are there any distribution revenues, or did they all flow through management fees from an accounting perspective?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, they flow through management fees from an accounting perspective. So that's the non-U.S. assets. And as I've mentioned, it's the profitability. The profitability on the SICAV product is probably a little bit higher than the U.S. products. But that's
componenttext: Yes, they flow through management fees from an accounting perspective. So that's the non-U.S. assets. And as I've mentioned, it's the profitability. The profitability on the SICAV product is probably a little bit higher than the U.S. products. But that's not the only type of assets that we have in the international arena. So on average, the profitability of the international products and the U.S. products are about the same. So if you are incurring asset-based distribution expenses on the international products, you should see that on a dollar-for-dollar basis in the investment management fee line.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up on the balance sheet, saw that your cash went up, I'm just wondering if you can update on where the level of excess cash is? How much is domiciled outside the U.S. and if you have any plans for a special dividend in the account to yo
componenttext: And just a follow-up on the balance sheet, saw that your cash went up, I'm just wondering if you can update on where the level of excess cash is? How much is domiciled outside the U.S. and if you have any plans for a special dividend in the account to your fourth quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at cash and investments, it's split about evenly, U.S. and non-U.S. on a like cash and cash equivalents basis. It's probably about 40% to 45% U.S. We'll clarify that in the 10-K. And then in terms of share repurchases and dividends, really, n
componenttext: If you look at cash and investments, it's split about evenly, U.S. and non-U.S. on a like cash and cash equivalents basis. It's probably about 40% to 45% U.S. We'll clarify that in the 10-K. And then in terms of share repurchases and dividends, really, no change from the prior, still committed to both of those and still committed to returning a great proportion of earnings to shareholders through repurchases and dividends.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Lee with KBW.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Lee with KBW.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have questions on the comp. I mean, you guys have done a pretty good job over the, I think, the last several years, keeping comp down in part because I think peak season you've grown headcount on a net basis or there's been a lot of shift towards lower
componenttext: I have questions on the comp. I mean, you guys have done a pretty good job over the, I think, the last several years, keeping comp down in part because I think peak season you've grown headcount on a net basis or there's been a lot of shift towards lower cost regions, I guess, I'll use that phrase. But did you feel like you have more room there? Are you starting to feel the comp pressures maybe are starting to grow? I mean you're back towards kind of peak asset levels and pretty close to peak revenue levels, profitabilities' been pretty much restored. I mean are starting to see kind of building pressures on the comp line? Or is there ability to continue to kind of manage, relatively speaking, manage down comp as you move bodies around the world?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there are two different components to that, kind of the fixed component and the variable component. Certainly, we think we've done a pretty good job and we're pretty good at utilizing those low-cost regions. And that's where having headcount. We
componenttext: I think there are two different components to that, kind of the fixed component and the variable component. Certainly, we think we've done a pretty good job and we're pretty good at utilizing those low-cost regions. And that's where having headcount. We can have maybe like 25%, 30% of the total employee population in those centers. So on a fixed-cost basis, we're managing it down on the variable side. I think it will vary with revenue as it has, and that will continue. I don't think that we're seeing any particular pressure to change any of that.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe on a different topic.You have Darby and I believe you have a real estate business and some other alternative products here and there. But can you talk about kind of your plans are for the alternative space? I mean, certainly, you're seeing a lot of
componenttext: Maybe on a different topic.You have Darby and I believe you have a real estate business and some other alternative products here and there. But can you talk about kind of your plans are for the alternative space? I mean, certainly, you're seeing a lot of demand there broadly speaking and a lot of your conditional competitors thinking about through lift-outs, acquisitions or internal development of expanding their own portfolio, alternative strategies, obsolete return strategies, however you want to define them. I mean, can you update us on you're thinking there? Is there anything kind of on the drawing board? Is that a part of your M&A strategy at this point?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take that one. I think as we've stated before, we believe it's going to be an important in growing area in our business. It's a natural complement to what we do. And as you've said or stated, we do have pockets what would be categorized as alternati
componenttext: I'll take that one. I think as we've stated before, we believe it's going to be an important in growing area in our business. It's a natural complement to what we do. And as you've said or stated, we do have pockets what would be categorized as alternatives within the firm. And we think we will have more of those type pockets in the future. We've had lot of discussions with a lot of different type of alternative managers and are continuing to do that. And we expect in the next year or so, that we would see some additions to the firm. I think one of our concerns has always been that we want to make sure that, especially whether it's hedge funds or people-intensive businesses, that it's something that has a process that is transferable all and that we can make sure that we're locking up the value that created those returns. So we have been somewhat careful there. And I think another area we've had a lot of conversations around is our strategy has always been generally to own more than 50%. And I think we've recognized that maybe a stepped approach makes more sense when looking at some of the newer alternative managers. So we are looking for minority stakes to build towards majority over time. Another area that we're building out and where you'd hear a lot in the business is around solutions. And to me, it's also in with what we're doing with alternatives. And we have added resources there, and whether it's building more outcome-oriented products, more tactical asset allocation funds, those are all the kind of things that we're building, as well as inflation hedge-type products, where we can bring commodities and have a place to go if rates move up. So that, I think as far as an area that we're the most active in, it would be certainly, in building out that solutions capability. And then within that, bringing in alternative managers to complement that.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Carrier with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Carrier with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess one more question on the institutional, and think you guys might have in the past broken this down. I don't see it now and you might have done that in the pre-recording call. But do you have the breakdown of just where the flows are, and maybe X-
componenttext: I guess one more question on the institutional, and think you guys might have in the past broken this down. I don't see it now and you might have done that in the pre-recording call. But do you have the breakdown of just where the flows are, and maybe X-ing out the remaining mandate, just overall? So if you could take like the $14 billion, $15 billion, how much of that is retail versus institutional? And then on the institutional side, just what you're seeing in terms of the trends, U.S. institutional versus like non-U.S. institutional?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we don't have it broken out between the institutional and retail. And as we mentioned, $4.6 billion of the net number was due to the one institutional account with the dual fund in Romania. As far as trends, quarter-over-quarter, I me
componenttext: Well, first of all, we don't have it broken out between the institutional and retail. And as we mentioned, $4.6 billion of the net number was due to the one institutional account with the dual fund in Romania. As far as trends, quarter-over-quarter, I mean, I think, I would, other than global bonds, in some case declining outside of U.S., really looking at global equities and every other category between retail institutions, I'd say it's very stable as far as the mix. And looking at again, the backlog, in searches, in the pipeline, in the wins and losses, there was nothing really significant over the quarter. A lot of 200 , 300 -- $200 million accounts that were funded during the quarter and some went out as well and both of them in the global equity category, as well as the global ag. And we continue to see a lot of searches, especially in fixed income outside of the United States. We expect to fund some of those in the quarter ahead that we won over this quarter. And it's really the same trends that we've been talking about, I think, over the last probably three or four quarters with regard to the institutional pipeline.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Ken, you gave some color on the different expense lines on the pre-recording call. I guess the two line items that stick out is the IT tech occupancy and in advertising. Both, you've guided towards that they were heading higher. It's just the i
componenttext: And then, Ken, you gave some color on the different expense lines on the pre-recording call. I guess the two line items that stick out is the IT tech occupancy and in advertising. Both, you've guided towards that they were heading higher. It's just the increase sequentially was roughly $10 million in each bucket. So you mentioned some could be seasonal. There could be one-off items. But is this a good run rate? Or maybe it pulls back a little bit, but there's going to be growth over the next couple of quarters. Just any sense there?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it did. IT did it. It bumped up this quarter by a fair amount. And I think that some of that was -- I talked about earlier calls, just increased business activity because we knew that we were embarking on new projects after the slowdown a couple of
componenttext: Yes, it did. IT did it. It bumped up this quarter by a fair amount. And I think that some of that was -- I talked about earlier calls, just increased business activity because we knew that we were embarking on new projects after the slowdown a couple of years ago. So I think that will continue. But certainly, some of it was for things that were unique. They may reoccur in future quarters but it's not like a trend that I'd say. So I think just the quarter numbers was a little high in terms of the run rate. That's on the IT side. And on the advertising and promotion, that, too, is a little high. But keep in mind that some of that is driven by sales and assets under management, so I don't think that we are spending more. So I don't think that it goes back to levels we saw last year, but I think it's probably a little high for a run rate as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Q on the underwriting and distribution expense. So first, what portion of the underwriting expense are actually from international products? So you have like $529 million. What portion is attributed to international?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: I'd say the piece -- well, first of all, international assets are about 30% of total. And then, I'd say the distribution expenses is around that level as well. But I think the piece that everybody's thinking about where there's a mismatch between line items, that's probably like in the 12% to 15% of the total line item, if that make sense.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: What's that 12% to 15% of what line item?
componenttext: What's that 12% to 15% of what line item?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: There's a piece where that expense goes up, and you should see $1 more of investment management fee revenue. That's about, I'd call it, 10% to 15% of the total underwriting distribution expense line.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: And the second question there is, how are foreign distributors paid? I guess, what portion would be upfront on a sale versus over time on the assets?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's what makes this conversation so difficult because it's very dependent on the class of shares. And there's a lot of share classes on the products. So there's some that are upfront and there's some that are ongoing, and it's hard to quantify the mix
componenttext: That's what makes this conversation so difficult because it's very dependent on the class of shares. And there's a lot of share classes on the products. So there's some that are upfront and there's some that are ongoing, and it's hard to quantify the mix.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I guess, what I'm hopefully after is, you had a negative underwriting revenue this quarter. If it's all based on assets and there's no reason for that negative number to perk up next quarter, but if you got a lot up front, you had a good sales quarter
componenttext: So I guess, what I'm hopefully after is, you had a negative underwriting revenue this quarter. If it's all based on assets and there's no reason for that negative number to perk up next quarter, but if you got a lot up front, you had a good sales quarter, sales go down our normalize then the net underwriting revenue can pop back nicely to positive. So I guess, what your answer is it can pop nicely back to positive because of some of the fees are upfront.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, some are upfront. But I think as the percentage of the asset-based fee, the one that goes up with assets under management, as we see the increase in international assets under management, then it's possible that, that would go the other way. So you
componenttext: Yes, some are upfront. But I think as the percentage of the asset-based fee, the one that goes up with assets under management, as we see the increase in international assets under management, then it's possible that, that would go the other way. So you could see that pop to negative. But again, it doesn't affect the overall company's profitability.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Marc Irizarry with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Marc Irizarry with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the operating margin again. It seems like there's a lot of geography issues in terms of where in the P&L sort of items are coming up. But when you think about the core margins for this quarter and you think about the advertising expense and the m
componenttext: Just on the operating margin again. It seems like there's a lot of geography issues in terms of where in the P&L sort of items are coming up. But when you think about the core margins for this quarter and you think about the advertising expense and the mix shift in the business potentially towards equity that you're trying to drive with some of the advertising, what's the expectation for the operating margin here going forward?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, as you know, since so much of that revenue is driven by the margin is kind of a futile exercise of trying to pinpoint the margin in any given quarter. But you can just see by the mere fact that the assets under management have increased last quarter,
componenttext: So, as you know, since so much of that revenue is driven by the margin is kind of a futile exercise of trying to pinpoint the margin in any given quarter. But you can just see by the mere fact that the assets under management have increased last quarter, just based on that fact alone, it would be reasonable to expect some improvement in the operating margin next quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on capital redeployment, in terms of priorities, if there were to be a change in tax laws and as far as dividend tax laws go next year, how are you guys thinking about the special dividend relative to buying back stock? I  mean, where is so
componenttext: And then just on capital redeployment, in terms of priorities, if there were to be a change in tax laws and as far as dividend tax laws go next year, how are you guys thinking about the special dividend relative to buying back stock? I  mean, where is sort of taxes playing into that thinking?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, certainly that is a consideration and a decision. At the end of the day, it's up to the Board of Directors to decide and that's kind of where we're at. But there's really been no change in sentiment. But certainly, we'll be keeping an eye on what's
componenttext: Yes, certainly that is a consideration and a decision. At the end of the day, it's up to the Board of Directors to decide and that's kind of where we're at. But there's really been no change in sentiment. But certainly, we'll be keeping an eye on what's going on with the taxes. And that would be an part of the decision process.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Douglas Sipkin with Ticonderoga.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Douglas Sipkin with Ticonderoga.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So obviously, we've seen a lot of acquisitions in this space in some of your competitors and a lot of consolidation on the distribution front. You guys have been pretty constant throughout. Can you just talk about how you're standing amongst distributors
componenttext: So obviously, we've seen a lot of acquisitions in this space in some of your competitors and a lot of consolidation on the distribution front. You guys have been pretty constant throughout. Can you just talk about how you're standing amongst distributors, wire houses or that has changed? Is that all over the last year or two years? And how is that playing at all to some of the flows you guys are seeing?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're in very good shape. And obviously, it's having the right mix and we think is a pretty good marketing and distribution effort behind it. But this year, as far as net flows within the non-proprietary channel, we were the top seller on a
componenttext: Well, I think we're in very good shape. And obviously, it's having the right mix and we think is a pretty good marketing and distribution effort behind it. But this year, as far as net flows within the non-proprietary channel, we were the top seller on a net basis. And I think number two, on a gross basis. And in terms of distribution outside of the U.S. across the border sales, we were number 1 both on gross and net. So you're not number 1 with everyone of your distributors. But again looking at the entire universe of distribution, we're probably 1 or 2 in most of the nature distributors out there. So I would say that we are extremely well positioned. And not only really gross and net, but we were fortunate to increase market share in fixed income. So it really wasn't just having the right funds and having the big wave come with it. We actually, significantly increased our share in the fixed income space, again, both in the U.S. and offshore and equity as well. And if you look at -- I mentioned rising dividends with Franklin growth bond, which is in the top quartile for the 1, 3, 5 and 10. For us, it really addresses what has been a significant deficiency. As far as our asset concentration, that's gaining market share. So that's positive as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just to follow up, in terms of the big mandate for global equity this quarter, I believe that came in right at the end of quarter's who are really not too much of a revenue contributor. I don't know if you guys have provided the revenue yield on that
componenttext: And just to follow up, in terms of the big mandate for global equity this quarter, I believe that came in right at the end of quarter's who are really not too much of a revenue contributor. I don't know if you guys have provided the revenue yield on that, that maybe we should be thinking about moving forward to getting a full quarter of it now?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: The way to look at it is it's in line with institutional mandate of that investment objective. And it's $4 billion on 600 plus, so it won't have the material impact on the effective fee rate, I don't think.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe, Greg, I think a lot of us talk to you all the time about the cyclical component of the flows. But I guess, given your dominant presence in the retails channel, I'm curious what your wholesalers tell you, what the field tells you in terms
componenttext: And then maybe, Greg, I think a lot of us talk to you all the time about the cyclical component of the flows. But I guess, given your dominant presence in the retails channel, I'm curious what your wholesalers tell you, what the field tells you in terms of clearly where the flows are going now, whether it'd be fixing compares of alternatives? How do you assess the cyclical versus secular argument of domestic equity? And how does that impact just how you think about the infrastructure you have now and building new funds, strategic stuff?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as I've mentioned before, I don't see a big shift taking place to equities right now based on what we've seen at the start of the year. I think how we think about it is that we recognize that we need more shelf space on the equity front, and
componenttext: Yes, I think as I've mentioned before, I don't see a big shift taking place to equities right now based on what we've seen at the start of the year. I think how we think about it is that we recognize that we need more shelf space on the equity front, and that's something we've been the big pushing very hard over the last two years. And we've debated long and hard about going out and acquiring a firm to fill that. But I think what we realize is that we have it all in-house. And the performance record in Franklin Equity in the last year, 80% of the assets were in the top quartile. That's on top of a very strong long-term performance. So those funds are getting recognition now. And again, we mentioned the 20-20 vision campaign. So we've been out talking about equities in the decade ahead despite the headwinds that we're facing right now. So that's really our strategy is just like it was when equities were selling and fixed income was not doing a lot in inflows. We were out there telling the fixed-income story. So we think it's a great opportunity for us I mean, the distribution, they're not just paid on selling the global bond fund, they're incentives really work around talking about equities and even if it's incremental gains and just getting on a 401(k) platform. That's the goal right now. And really, I mean, in terms of defining that in numbers, I mean, I think that's hard to do but I can tell you, it's been a major priority for distribution to make sure that we're well positioned when it does move. I just don't think it's moving right now.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to all those points and maybe next time, we will have this color. It would be helpful to see what incremental placements there are because we can see how good the performance records are, right? However you define it in terms of on the focus list, on
componenttext: And to all those points and maybe next time, we will have this color. It would be helpful to see what incremental placements there are because we can see how good the performance records are, right? However you define it in terms of on the focus list, on approved list, on the buy list, however each firm does their individual focus list, that could help because the performance looks like it's there, to your point, if and when the flows turn, you should benefit.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would be happy to share that.
componenttext: I would be happy to share that.

componenttext: On EPS, I know it's a product that you haven't really shown much interest in the past. But as I look at across some of your peers, several of them are at least putting the exempt of relief absent because they take a while just to sort of have it as a placeholder. Maybe they don't know what they want to do with it yet but I kind of think about how it's organic to your leg, in event. Is there any thing you would think of doing or not?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you want we want to keep your options open, so that's probably not a bad strategy. As we've said before, they're here to say and they're going to grow quickly and make the active manager's job more difficult. But our feeling is still that t
componenttext: Well, I think you want we want to keep your options open, so that's probably not a bad strategy. As we've said before, they're here to say and they're going to grow quickly and make the active manager's job more difficult. But our feeling is still that the majority of those flows are going to go into the bigger funds with the top three managers, and it's going to be a fee battle that we're already starting to see unfold. So like money funds, we just think there's a big enough pool to focus on active management. And that's just really we think why the value proposition of the company. But I think that is a valid point. I mean, you want to keep your options and if they're changing things around, actively managed EPS, we'd want to be able to participate in that. But it's also -- we feel like there's enough out there where acquisition would be a quicker route to if we really want to move into that space versus building.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the majority of the global bond flows are in retail. So I think I was just speaking in general terms about equity versus fixed income. And also, our fourth quarter tends to be the slower summer months. So you would expect to see that pick up as peo
componenttext: Well, the majority of the global bond flows are in retail. So I think I was just speaking in general terms about equity versus fixed income. And also, our fourth quarter tends to be the slower summer months. So you would expect to see that pick up as people get back in the offices. And I think those trends are all are very much in place. There's not a lot of searches in pure global bond, that's global lag and emerging market bonds, which we've seen just a consistent level of searches. And I think for us, with the strength we have in many of the emerging markets and many areas of sovereign wealth funds, it's a natural fit for those type of funds. So we're continuing to see good opportunities there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: I mean to me, this is a question we get quite a bit. But it's probably the largest and most liquid market out there. So we really haven't seen any restraints. I think if anything, you could argue that this fund historically moved into a little bit esoteric market, less liquid ones and with size, it has been a little bit more restricted on doing that over time. But the bigger markets that it moves in and really adds outlook from making currency bits are huge markets. So we're not seeing any real constraints there.

componenttext: Well, I mean, the non-U.S. portion is indefinitely reinvested in the operations outside the U.S. and that's kind of our approach, and we're going to continue with that. headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to our Second Quarter Earnings Commentary for 2010. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. We are pleased to report another solid quarter, highlighted by record net new flows of $17.5 billion, led by a strong increase in
componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to our Second Quarter Earnings Commentary for 2010. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. We are pleased to report another solid quarter, highlighted by record net new flows of $17.5 billion, led by a strong increase in retail flows outside the U.S. and a recovery in institutional flows globally. International sales more than tripled from the year-ago quarter and were almost half of total sales this quarter. International assets increased to 28% of total assets under management as of March 31, driven by strong growth in our cross-border SICAV funds that exceeded $80 billion in assets under management at March 31. And most importantly, relative investment performance remains strong with at least 85% of assets in the top 2 Lipper quartiles for the 3-, 5- and 10-year periods.
Turn to AUM. Assets under management ended the quarter at $587 billion, an increase of 6% from the prior quarter and more importantly, up 50% from the prior year. Simple monthly average AUM for the quarter was $551 billion or a 5% increase from the prior quarter. Assets under management via investment objectives shifted towards fixed income at 36% of ending assets under management. Equity is 45% and hybrid, 18%.
Turning to flows. The increase in assets under management was due to market appreciation of $16.5 billion and an 18% increase in the long-term net new flows as a result of increased long-term sales, especially outside of the U.S. 7 of our 10 largest funds had inflows and 45 of our U.S. registered mutual funds had annualized pre-market organic growth of at least 10% this quarter. U.S. long-term sales and redemptions increased slightly from the prior quarter as we continue to benefit from the U.S. retail's investors' preference for fixed-income investments.
The Templeton Global Bond fund was our best-selling U.S. fund with approximately $5 billion in net new flows. Following the free flows, the U.S. equity funds remain in redemption. Global equity flows have turned positive. However, our largest Templeton funds were still in outflows during the quarter, despite strong relative performance. Our U.S. institutional business continues to improve and March was our best month in more than 2 years.
International was the big story for us this quarter with long-term sales increasing 20% from last quarter. Our cross-border SICAV funds had approximately $11 billion in net new flows, led by strong flows in Italy where we are now the second-largest foreign asset manager with assets over $10 billion. These flows tend to be a little bit more volatile over various market cycles.
Non-U.S. investors have been less risk-aversed and we've seen positive equity flows, particularly in our regional equity strategy such as the Asian growth that had over $1 billion in net new flows. Fixed income though remains in favor and the SICAV version of the Templeton Global Bond funds had approximately $5 billion of net new flows, while our global total return and emerging market bond funds also had strong flows.
Turning to flows by investment objective. Equity outflows improved from last quarter on increased sales and decreased redemptions. Global equity had the biggest improvement in net new flows as inflows across Europe and Asia were offset by outflows in the U.S. and Canada. Hybrid products had $1 billion of net new flows led by Franklin Income fund at $300 million in net inflows and its SICAV version at $170 million of net inflows, as well as continued high net worth inflows of $230 million. Fixed income products had another strong quarter with $17.3 billion in net new flows, an 11% increase from the prior quarter and looking at the Templeton Global Bond fund sales for the U.S. and SICAV, it represented approximately 27% of overall growth sales. Tax free also continues to be a good story for us with $1.3 billion in net new flows for the quarter and cash management had outflows of $400 million.
Turning to investment performance. The overall relative investment performance remains strong with at least 85% of assets in top 2 Lipper quartiles with 3-, 5- and 10-year prior periods. Our 1-year numbers flipped a bit, but generally remain strong as short-term relative performance tends to bounce around a bit from period to period and we continue to focus on delivering strong, long-term performance because that's what our clients are looking for.
The biggest change in performance rankings was Mutual Series where our 3 remaining funds slipped into the bottom 2 quartiles for the 1-year period. Mutual Series' absolute 1-year performance is a strong plus 30% to plus 50% for the funds. However, the overweight positions in cash, as we've mentioned on prior calls, has created drag on relative performance. Also, Mutual Series tends to lag momentum-type markets like we've seen over the last year.
We also had a decrease in the 1-year Templeton relative performance and most of that was through the Templeton World fund that represents about 20% of assets in the category and the Templeton World fund just slipped to the 51st percentile. I now turn it over to Ken for operating results.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Operating income for the quarter was at $461 million, a slight decrease from last quarter due to seasonal factors such as 2 less days in the quarter.Net income was $356.7 million and earnings per share was $1.55. As a reminder, last quarte
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Operating income for the quarter was at $461 million, a slight decrease from last quarter due to seasonal factors such as 2 less days in the quarter.
Net income was $356.7 million and earnings per share was $1.55. As a reminder, last quarter, we adopted a dual share class method of calculating earnings per share that effectively reduces net income by approximately 0.5% to 0.75% of 1% or approximately $0.01 of diluted EPS this quarter.
On Slide 17, investment management fees increased 4%, slightly less than the increase in simple monthly average assets under management, due primarily to 2 less days in the quarter and $3.7 million less in performance fees. The effective fee rate for the quarter was 60.3 basis points, excluding performance fees and adjusting for the number of days in the quarter, and that compares with 59.4 basis points last quarter.
Underwriting and distribution fees increased 2%. While underwriting and distribution expenses increased 4%. Impacting the change from prior quarter was, as previously noted, a non-recurring gain of approximately $3 million included in the first quarter fees. While the impact of net underwriting and distribution fees on operating income was de minimis, several factors impact these lines, as they're primarily based on average net assets and commissionable growth sales.
To complicate matters further, some of the asset-based revenue is computed on a daily basis NAV basis, while the expenses paid to dealers are paid on a monthly basis. So the short quarter had an impact on the margin as well. Shareholder service fees increased by $2 million and that's consistent with the increase in billable accounts. And other net revenue was $8.3 million and included a non-recurring decrease in revenue of $1.4 million.
Slide 18 shows that operating expenses increased 5% from the prior quarter, due primarily to the usual seasonal increases, as well as increased variable expenses in strategic investments, due to improving business conditions. Compensation and benefits increased 7% due to seasonal impact of merit increases awarded in December and increased payroll taxes. Also contributing to the change was increased variable compensation, including the first full quarter impact of performance share awards. This looks like a pretty good run rate for the rest of the fiscal year.
Advertising and promotion expenses increased 9% due to equal increases in marketing support and advertising expenses that were partially offset by lower other expenses. In the first quarter, we launched a new television commercial as part of our Reflections ad campaign that was named Ad Campaign of the Year by Fund Action. I would expect this quarterly amount to increase significantly over the latter half of the fiscal year, possibly approaching levels last seen in 2008.
Amortization and deferred sales commissions was pretty much flat from the prior quarter, due to increases in A and C share classes that were offset by lower B share amortization. And this too looks like a pretty good run rate for next quarter, but I would expect that this line to taper off slightly beginning in the fourth quarter as the B share amortization runs off. Other expenses increased only slightly due to increased consulting and other professional fees.
Turning to Slide 19. Other income net was flat from the prior quarter at $47 million. Consolidated sponsored investment products income was $5.6 million, representing the mark-to-market increase of the securities held by those sponsored products, classified as trading on our balance sheet. Investment in Other income net was $42 million, an increase of $9.5 million from the prior quarter and that was due mostly to increased earnings from equity method, investees and realized and unrealized foreign exchange gains that were partially offset by lower gains on the sale of investments.
Full details will be in our filings as usual. The effective tax rate for the quarter was 29.5%, due to the decrease in the fiscal year-to-date effective tax rate of 30.3%, which is slightly below the range we were estimating last quarter.
The operating margin on Slide 20 was 32.6% for the quarter. And regarding capital management, we repurchased 1.1 million shares this quarter, decreasing ending shares outstanding to 227.4 million shares. The trailing 12-month payout ratio was 104%. That was elevated slightly, due to the $3 special cash dividend paid in December. In total, cash and investments were approximately $5.7 billion versus $5.4 billion at December 31, 2009. So that concludes my comments, I'll turn it back to Greg.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ken. As this quarter's results show, we continue to benefit from the depth and breadth of our global presence as momentum continues to build in many countries. Because of our strong financial position, we were able to continue to invest in growth
componenttext:
Thanks, Ken. As this quarter's results show, we continue to benefit from the depth and breadth of our global presence as momentum continues to build in many countries. Because of our strong financial position, we were able to continue to invest in growth opportunities during the market downturn and those efforts are paying off in countries such as Italy, Chile and Malaysia.
During the quarter, we were also appointed Investment Manager of the Romanian Property Fund. Assets valued at around EUR 2.4 billion or USD 3.3 billion. However, this mandate is not expected to fund until early July so it is not in this quarter's numbers. As always, thank you for taking time to listen to this commentary. If you have any questions about the release or our comments, be sure to contact Investor Relations before the live call later today. Thank you.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. As always, we thank you for taking the time to join us today and we hope you've had a chance to listen to our prepared remarks which were available before the e
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. As always, we thank you for taking the time to join us today and we hope you've had a chance to listen to our prepared remarks which were available before the exchange opened this morning.
In short, we were pleased to report another solid quarter, highlighted by continued strong relative investment performance and record net new flows, including strong growth in gross sales across our broad range of offerings, particularly in our international products as momentum continues to build in many countries around the globe. I'd like to now open it up to your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our first question is from Bill Katz with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our first question is from Bill Katz with Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just from a big picture perspective, Greg. Could you talk a little bit about how you see the potential handoff, if at all, between fixed income and equity? And how you might be positioned for such a potential flow shift?
componenttext: Just from a big picture perspective, Greg. Could you talk a little bit about how you see the potential handoff, if at all, between fixed income and equity? And how you might be positioned for such a potential flow shift?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we feel that, that shift will occur maybe, it was starting a little bit over the last few months. I mean flows have certainly looked better. And our goal, just like when things were going gangbusters on the equity side, we were pushing hard
componenttext: Well, I think we feel that, that shift will occur maybe, it was starting a little bit over the last few months. I mean flows have certainly looked better. And our goal, just like when things were going gangbusters on the equity side, we were pushing hard on a fixed income campaign. And for the last 3 to 6 months, we've been, while we’re doing extremely well on the fixed income side, we've been out there talking about equities. We have a 20/20 Vision campaign, which has been received extremely well, and despite headwinds we're going to continue to talk about equities because we think that retail turn will happen and obviously, we want to be well-positioned. And I think we feel that we have a very strong lineup. And it's a matter of just again getting the attention on that lineup, and despite the record flows for the quarter, we still are making sure that the distribution is focused on getting that equity story out there. And I'm not sure when it will turn. I think we've all been frustrated that it's taken a bit longer. I think investor sentiment here in the United States for a lot of reasons continues to be a little bit shaky. We're not seeing that in other parts of the globe, we're not seeing that in Europe and Asia and I've seen a tremendous rebound in our sales, like the Asian Growth Fund that had $1.2 billion in net inflows for the quarter. So there are funds that are doing very well on the equity side, but like most in the U.S., we still remain frustrated that the investors are not moving back.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at your volumes outside the United States, this was a particularly strong quarter. I think almost $9 billion of inflow, about 25% growth rate on those assets. Can you talk a little bit about maybe some of the volume and the mix drivers to some
componenttext: If you look at your volumes outside the United States, this was a particularly strong quarter. I think almost $9 billion of inflow, about 25% growth rate on those assets. Can you talk a little bit about maybe some of the volume and the mix drivers to some of that growth, and maybe on a temporal basis, what might be happening into the middle part of April?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the, as I mentioned, I mean, the equity investor is back and whether it's Emerging Markets or more focused the Asian Growth Fund, those have been 2 good sellers for us on a net basis as well as Mutual Global Discovery Fund. There hasn't been
componenttext: Well, I think the, as I mentioned, I mean, the equity investor is back and whether it's Emerging Markets or more focused the Asian Growth Fund, those have been 2 good sellers for us on a net basis as well as Mutual Global Discovery Fund. There hasn't been a whole lot of chunky business moving. Actually, more of the bigger business on a separate account side was negative for the quarter in global equities where we had about a little over $700 billion between 2 accounts that were redeemed in the global equity side. So you are seeing a fair amount of strength on the retail side around the globe for global equities and obviously, global bonds, which had outside of the U.S., just a little over $5 billion in net inflows.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jeff Hopson with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jeff Hopson with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about the -- it looked like you had pretty good flows on the institutional side in Global Bond. So could you talk a little bit about that pipeline? And then also, you have other products on the global side, Global Income, I think, and some
componenttext: Could you talk about the -- it looked like you had pretty good flows on the institutional side in Global Bond. So could you talk a little bit about that pipeline? And then also, you have other products on the global side, Global Income, I think, and some others; they seem to be picking up some traction. How optimistic are you about those other products outside of the big Global Bond Fund?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we have seen continued interest in certainly the Emerging Market Debt is another one, Global Aggregate, Global Core and with a lot of the big sovereign wealth funds around the globe, there continues to be strong interest in those. I think, du
componenttext: Yes. I think we have seen continued interest in certainly the Emerging Market Debt is another one, Global Aggregate, Global Core and with a lot of the big sovereign wealth funds around the globe, there continues to be strong interest in those. I think, during this quarter, we had some fundings with Malaysia that we talked about last quarter, specifically in fixed income. So situations like that we continue to benefit from the brand presence in a lot of those markets. And as those funds continue to grow, we're very optimistic that we're in a good position to continue to capture that. So we think, as we've talked about in prior quarters, that's certainly an incremental area for growth and we have been getting the benefit of that in the last few quarters and I think that's going to continue.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And like in February, you had no issues with Greece and I suspect that's still the case and if anything, you may have benefited from the fact that you didn't have exposure there. So would you say the same type of situation is still there, right now?
componenttext: And like in February, you had no issues with Greece and I suspect that's still the case and if anything, you may have benefited from the fact that you didn't have exposure there. So would you say the same type of situation is still there, right now?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as I know, that's the case and certainly it was the case when the contagion hit originally that we didn't have any exposure there. So I think that the performance should look even better through this period.
componenttext: Yes, as far as I know, that's the case and certainly it was the case when the contagion hit originally that we didn't have any exposure there. So I think that the performance should look even better through this period.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is from Mike Carrier of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, I think on the recorded call, you were mentioning that the institutional, you hit like the best month in March in 2 years. Just wondering, one, is that overall? Or I thought it might've been just U.S. and then if it was in the U.S, where was the str
componenttext: Greg, I think on the recorded call, you were mentioning that the institutional, you hit like the best month in March in 2 years. Just wondering, one, is that overall? Or I thought it might've been just U.S. and then if it was in the U.S, where was the strength coming from the products?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it was both. It was in the U.S. and some of that, again, it's not always a clean line between institutional in separate accounts and retail. And some of that was some wins on the annuity side where we had some chunkier wins during the quarter
componenttext: Yes, I think it was both. It was in the U.S. and some of that, again, it's not always a clean line between institutional in separate accounts and retail. And some of that was some wins on the annuity side where we had some chunkier wins during the quarter there. And continued just, I think overall, very consistent performance in the U.S. through the consultants, the typical business on the global equity side. So nothing really big to call out. I mean, I think it was just of little wins that are probably a healthier way to go.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ken, just on the expenses. The one item that you didn't mention was just on the IT. I just wanted to see any outlook there because you gave pretty good, detailed guidance on all the other line items. And then just on the cash use. You guys continue to buy
componenttext: Ken, just on the expenses. The one item that you didn't mention was just on the IT. I just wanted to see any outlook there because you gave pretty good, detailed guidance on all the other line items. And then just on the cash use. You guys continue to buy back stock, but just looking forward, given the cash balance, any expectations versus historically where your buybacks had been?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the IT line. I think I'd mentioned on some previous calls that there's an expectation that spending will increase there. But it's slow. These projects take a long time. So I would suggest that trend will continue. And then on the cash, no real di
componenttext: Sure. On the IT line. I think I'd mentioned on some previous calls that there's an expectation that spending will increase there. But it's slow. These projects take a long time. So I would suggest that trend will continue. And then on the cash, no real difference on kind of our philosophy on that. I’m definitely committed to generating a very competitive total return to shareholders, share repurchases, a tool that we use for sure on that. I think we're in the market pretty regularly, but we tend to be opportunistic and I think that will continue.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is from Cynthia Mayer with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was going to ask you about IT, too. So I'll just ask a very quick follow-up on that. Once you start spending on IT, maybe if you just give a sense of how much -- how the incremental amount relates to what you already have in that line. And also, is that
componenttext: I was going to ask you about IT, too. So I'll just ask a very quick follow-up on that. Once you start spending on IT, maybe if you just give a sense of how much -- how the incremental amount relates to what you already have in that line. And also, is that the kind of thing that's like a step function. Or it’s just a little bit more every quarter for a little while?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I probably should point out there's more on that line than IT. There's certainly occupancy and facilities costs in that line, so that drives that line a little bit. But with regarding IT, it's a combination. There's ongoing maintenance that you can
componenttext: Well, I probably should point out there's more on that line than IT. There's certainly occupancy and facilities costs in that line, so that drives that line a little bit. But with regarding IT, it's a combination. There's ongoing maintenance that you can see gradually increase. We did pull back during the market downturn; we pulled back on some of the maintenance items. So that type of expense, I think you'll see sequentially quarter-over-quarter. And then the larger projects is more of a step function. It takes a while to put on. Some of them get capitalized and then you start to see it in the depreciation number.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the flows. You mentioned greater appetite for equity out of the U.S. Is that just Asia? Or are you just finding it's worldwide? It's Europe, too?
componenttext: And then in terms of the flows. You mentioned greater appetite for equity out of the U.S. Is that just Asia? Or are you just finding it's worldwide? It's Europe, too?

componenttext: It's Europe as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So on the Templeton Global Bond, just a couple of questions there. At what point does capacity start to be a factor? Two, who are the incremental buyers of the fund? And three, to what extent does the management team, do you guys as the management team, h
componenttext: So on the Templeton Global Bond, just a couple of questions there. At what point does capacity start to be a factor? Two, who are the incremental buyers of the fund? And three, to what extent does the management team, do you guys as the management team, have concerns about how this fund performs in a rising rate environment?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, first of all, capacity in any of our funds is something that we're concerned about and if the portfolio managers feel that it's time to consider closing a fund, we will do that. And we've done that in the past, so that's something we're ver
componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, capacity in any of our funds is something that we're concerned about and if the portfolio managers feel that it's time to consider closing a fund, we will do that. And we've done that in the past, so that's something we're very aware of. But I think that the general statement regarding flows and where we had $10 billion of net inflows was into a global government bond fund. And a government bond fund, obviously, you have tremendous capacity and growing capacity. And then also currency is the other area. So the liquidity of derivatives around currency forwards and things that you have to use in a fund like that, again, it’s one of the most liquid in large markets. So while we have a large share of a new class of flows, it is dwarfed by the overall size of that market. So there's really very little concern. If you had that much going in Emerging Markets Debt, that may be a different discussion on liquidity to consider having to close. I think the question around buyers is an interesting one because I think part of this growth is the recognition, certainly on the retail side, of a new asset class that is less correlated in a way to typical fixed income to equities. It had a very strong overall performance number and obviously, active management is the only way to really play that market. And trying to get currencies right, obviously, is very challenging as well. But we've had a team that has been successful in doing that. And I think looking at the average retail investor, they're more open to putting a portion of their assets in that. So I think that's part of what you're seeing in that class, and it's still a very relatively small number of the typical retail investor's portfolio. So I think that's a good trend that bodes well for continued new investors in that category. And then finally on rates, I think you're a little bit less sensitive to rates and we do -- I mean, obviously, it’s fixed income. Currencies are going to be a big driver, but we also look at duration and are very focused then because it's not as much of an income-oriented fund. We can go a little bit shorter on duration than our typical longer-term maturity fixed income fund. So that helps a little bit. But the bottom line is that it's very challenging to manage in this space. And there are going to be times when you're going to be out of favor and wrong. To us, we're trying to build that into the selling process that, that should be part of your expectation. You're never going to call every move in currencies, but I think we feel like we've got one of the best teams out there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Robert Lee with KBW.
componenttext: Our next question is from Robert Lee with KBW.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question on the regulatory front or legal front. Who knows what happens if the Dodd bill has been included in that is obviously the, I guess, the Volcker Rules. And unfortunately for you guys, if I remember correctly, you are regulated as a bank
componenttext: I have a question on the regulatory front or legal front. Who knows what happens if the Dodd bill has been included in that is obviously the, I guess, the Volcker Rules. And unfortunately for you guys, if I remember correctly, you are regulated as a bank holding company. So I know nothing has been set in stone. But what flexibility -- I mean, do you have the flexibility if that came to pass to change your holding company structure? I assume you do so that you wouldn't be subject to any of the rules as it relates to private equity or other holdings?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as you said, I mean, it's hard because things are moving so quickly and the bottom line is we don't have to be a bank holding company. It's a complementary part of a few of our businesses that even today, we're looking at the overall structur
componenttext: Yes, I think as you said, I mean, it's hard because things are moving so quickly and the bottom line is we don't have to be a bank holding company. It's a complementary part of a few of our businesses that even today, we're looking at the overall structure and trying to rationalize the right future, but we can't really do that until we know what the regulatory landscape is going to look like. So you're right. I mean, today, we fall under that, under the Volcker Rule. You probably -- I'm not even sure we can seed funds. I'm not sure how any of these would work in practice. And I think we've got a long ways to go before we get too worried about what impact it may or may not have. But I think the bottom line is we feel even in the worst-case scenario that we could restructure the business and not have a big impact to get it from a different structure away from the Fed structure. But even that, there's been discussion that: well, we're not going to allow people to switch. So I'm not sure what that means either. I just think things are moving in a very fluid rate now. We're participating in Washington where we can, but I don't feel that there's anything there today that would present a huge challenge for us.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe shifting to the institutional business. Just curious, I mean, a couple of competitors here or there have talked about being impacted in the quarter by client re-balancing, kind of taking advantage of the rebounds in the market for the past year
componenttext: And maybe shifting to the institutional business. Just curious, I mean, a couple of competitors here or there have talked about being impacted in the quarter by client re-balancing, kind of taking advantage of the rebounds in the market for the past year and using that as an opportunity to re-balance. Generally, it seems like a way from long-only equity strategies to some extent. I mean, it doesn't seem like that's impacted your business much in the quarter. Can you just comment a little bit? Did you see some of that? And maybe at what pockets it was in, if you did see it. Or why do you think maybe that didn't affect you guys as much in the quarter?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we did see it. I think we've seen it the last 2 or 3 quarters and the re-balancing. And any time that you have a sector do well, like Global Equities or Emerging Markets, they tend to -- there’ll be a little bit of trim into those certain a
componenttext: Yes. I think we did see it. I think we've seen it the last 2 or 3 quarters and the re-balancing. And any time that you have a sector do well, like Global Equities or Emerging Markets, they tend to -- there’ll be a little bit of trim into those certain accounts. So we have seen that, they're just not -- I think on a relative basis, they're not big numbers. They're relatively small.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have seen a pickup. And we've seen a pick-up and one of the ways we measure these campaigns internally is the number of new advisers selling equity funds. And that's an important metric for us. And we have been hitting a new audience really every month
componenttext: We have seen a pickup. And we've seen a pick-up and one of the ways we measure these campaigns internally is the number of new advisers selling equity funds. And that's an important metric for us. And we have been hitting a new audience really every month. And so that's been a nice positive. We've seen positive flows going into our equity funds like the Franklin Growth Fund and the rising dividends and so the focus has been there. It's just on a relative basis compared to everything else, it's dwarfed. But the numbers are positive and they are growing. I think just overall from the retail, in terms of general statements, Mutual Series in the U.S. has had outflows. So that's put a little bit of drag on just looking at the U.S. equity numbers. And a lot of that is somewhat expected for us when you've had the higher cash positions, and their deep values style tends to kind of underperform the kind of market that we've had over the last year. So I think it's -- we feel like we are getting the attention there. It's difficult, but I just don't think the overall landscape is going to change a whole lot in the next quarter or 2 as far as flows go.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: I wouldn't agree with that. I would clarify that I think it's more on an investment objective and less so on a jurisdictional basis. And generally speaking, I think the increase in sales internationally won't impact overall profitability that much. So it's more a question of the asset mix shifting to the equity assets.

componenttext: Just wanted to drill down a little bit more on the global fixed income. And I don't know if you guys have provided at booking. But how about on the institutional side? Are institutional investors seeing it that way as well?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, I don't have all of the data in front of me to tell you exactly how it breaks down institutionally. I can tell you that the majority, $10 billion of the net flows going into global bond funds split between the U.S. and international sales, obviously, make up the majority of the overall flows. We did have some separate account wins, and I don't have the aggregate number, but there were some at $300 million, $200 million and maybe we can help you further with the Investor Relations group. But I just don't have it broken out in front of me other than to give you the sense that within that category, it clearly is retail that is driving probably 80%, 90% of those flows and that's a guesstimate, but that's probably close.

componenttext: And then just in terms of -- I guesstimate it's fair to assume that the institutional demand hasn't really changed all that much. Or is the outlook for sort of global, emerging et cetera, increasing, or flattening or sort of decreasing from sort of a RFP standpoint?

componenttext: I think it's steady. I think it's a little bit different than the retail because it's not strictly the global bond or the global government bond fund. It's more geared towards Emerging Market Debt in some other cases, or Global Ag, Global Core. So it's a little bit different, and we still are seeing a very steady RFP flow in those categories.

But where --how do you look at where those are positioned vis-à-vis their cash balances today? Or when do you sort of annualize or get past some of the headwinds from a return on perspective that, that impacted?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there'll always be short-term challenges when you have investment styles that go to cash in some markets. And you're never going to -- again, you're never going to find that right in the short-term. And that's why we spend a lot of time talking ab
componenttext: I think there'll always be short-term challenges when you have investment styles that go to cash in some markets. And you're never going to -- again, you're never going to find that right in the short-term. And that's why we spend a lot of time talking about building 3- and 5- and 10-year track records. And I think people somewhat -- they expect that, but there always is a short-term orientation on results. And I think with the Mutual Series funds, the cash levels are down. They're down in the teens and low teens in most cases so you won't have the kind of drag that you had before. And hopefully for us, it's just how historically that group has run money. And in some cases, you're going to have these kinds of periods where they underperform. But again, if you look at the longer-term numbers and how strong they are, I think that's really more important than the 1-year number. And you look at something like the Franklin Income fund, for example, that we had short-term challenges. They’ve had sufficiently higher weightings in financial services. And during the period when financial service banks were in a lot of trouble, that fund underperformed. But quickly, it's really more uplift now in the numbers. And it's back to being a top performer for the 1-year period and that kind of smoothes out over the 3 and 5. And we've seen the quick rebound in flows there. And that was probably one of the most important funds for us as far as flows and continues to be very important to us going forward. But it shows you how quickly things can turn around on the short-term basis and not really hurt your long-term numbers when you have those little blips.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: And I guess my second question would be just around sort of the strategic outlook, particularly around M&A. What are the -- can you characterize the types of properties that are for sale at this point? I mean last year, obviously, there were the institutions -- asset management firms coming out of financial institution looking to raise capital, presumably less of that, although maybe some of the smaller institutions. Or are we sort of back to the sort of historical landscape in terms of diversification of ownership, generational issues, those types of things?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, yes, probably fair. I mean I think the day of the more distressed sales has probably passed. The one of manufacturing and distribution separating is probably somewhat passed. And then you'll always have generational transfers and just people that
componenttext: I think, yes, probably fair. I mean I think the day of the more distressed sales has probably passed. The one of manufacturing and distribution separating is probably somewhat passed. And then you'll always have generational transfers and just people that feel like their company will be better positioned within a larger institution. And I think some of that in this world, having gone through this cycle and risk management and how that becomes more important to the investor to be part of a larger organization. I think does create more smaller situations. And we've had a lot of conversations where that's been an important focus to them, the distribution side. And just the importance of being within a larger organization that has all the resources to make sure that you're looking at risk, and compliance, and everything, and more importantly, from their client size. So I think you will see a lot of opportunities, as always, in this industry. I mean, there's always opportunity out there and we're continuing to look at everything.
